choices.text: Aims to apply best available evidence gained from scientific method to clinical decision making
Research paper is investigated by the tools quoted in research paper itself to check validity
Opinions of medical professionals & researchers have been given least importance
Evidence is generated from weak & poor studies

questions.text: All of the following are true about ‘Evidence-based medicine’ except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Evidence is generated from weak & poor studies Evidence is generated from weak & poor studies – This statement is false because evidence-based medicine (EBM) relies on high-quality research, including randomized controlled trials (RCTs), systematic reviews, and meta-analyses, to guide clinical decision-making. The goal of EBM is to ensure that medical decisions are based on the best available, scientifically valid, and peer-reviewed evidence rather than weak or poorly conducted studies. Incorrect Options: A. Aims to apply best available evidence gained from scientific method to clinical decision making – This is true. EBM integrates clinical expertise with the best available external research and patient preferences to provide optimal healthcare outcomes. B. Research paper is investigated by the tools quoted in research paper itself to check validity – This is true. EBM includes critical appraisal of research papers using standardized methods such as risk-of-bias assessment tools to evaluate the validity and applicability of study findings. C. Opinions of medical professionals & researchers have been given least importance – This is true. In EBM, expert opinion is considered the lowest form of evidence because it is prone to bias. Instead, higher priority is given to well-designed clinical trials and systematic reviews

questions.text: Hypothesis is a:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Variable to be tested A hypothesis is a proposed explanation or assumption that is tested through research and experimentation. It is not yet verified but is formulated based on observations, prior knowledge, and theories. In scientific studies, a hypothesis serves as a statement that researchers seek to prove or disprove through experiments and data analysis. Since a hypothesis is something that needs to be tested and validated, it is correctly classified as a "variable to be tested." Incorrect Options: A. Axiom – This is incorrect because an axiom is a self-evident truth that does not require proof or testing. It is a fundamental principle or assumption accepted as true without the need for experimental validation, whereas a hypothesis requires testing. B. Verified variable – This is incorrect because a hypothesis is an assumption that has not yet been proven. A verified variable refers to something already tested and validated, whereas a hypothesis still needs to go through the research process. C. Established document – This is incorrect because a hypothesis is not a formal or established document. It is a testable statement used in research, and it may or may not be proven true. Established documents, such as laws or official guidelines, are already recognized and widely accepted.

questions.text: The extent to which a specific health care treatment service procedure program or other intervention does what it is intended to do when used in a community dwelling population is termed its :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Effectiveness Effectiveness refers to the real-world impact of a healthcare treatment, service, or intervention when applied to a general population in a community setting. It measures how well an intervention achieves its intended outcomes under routine conditions outside of controlled experimental settings. Unlike efficacy, which is tested in ideal and controlled environments, effectiveness reflects how well a treatment works in practical, everyday use. Incorrect Options: A. Efficacy – This is incorrect because efficacy refers to how well a treatment works under ideal and controlled conditions, such as in clinical trials. It does not necessarily indicate how successful it will be when applied in real-world scenarios. C. Effect modification – This is incorrect because effect modification refers to a situation where the effect of an intervention varies depending on another factor, such as age, gender, or genetic predisposition. It does not measure how well an intervention works in a community setting. D. Efficiency – This is incorrect because efficiency refers to the cost-effectiveness of an intervention, considering both resources used and outcomes achieved. While effectiveness measures success in achieving health outcomes, efficiency focuses on achieving the best results with the least cost and resources.

questions.text: Discovery of cholera by John Snow was a:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Natural Experiment Study John Snow’s discovery of cholera transmission in 1854 is considered a natural experiment study because he did not manipulate any variables but instead observed and analyzed naturally occurring conditions. He studied cholera outbreaks in London by comparing water sources from different suppliers and found that cases were more frequent in areas where people drank contaminated water from the Broad Street pump. His work provided strong epidemiological evidence that cholera was waterborne, even before the actual causative agent (Vibrio cholerae) was identified. Incorrect Options: A. Cohort Study – This is incorrect because cohort studies follow a group of people over time to compare disease occurrence between exposed and non-exposed individuals. John Snow’s investigation was retrospective and focused on a specific outbreak, not a long-term follow-up of exposed individuals. B. Cross-Sectional Study – This is incorrect because cross-sectional studies analyze data at a single point in time to assess the prevalence of a disease and its risk factors. Snow’s investigation involved tracing the source of infection over time, which does not fit the cross-sectional study design. D. Clinical Trial – This is incorrect because clinical trials involve controlled experiments, often with randomized assignment of treatments. Snow did not conduct an experiment but analyzed existing patterns of disease occurrence, making it an observational study rather than a trial.

questions.text: Hypothesis is not tested by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Descriptive Studies A hypothesis is a statement that can be tested through research to determine a relationship between variables. Descriptive studies do not test hypotheses because they focus on describing the characteristics of a population, event, or phenomenon rather than determining causal relationships. These studies do not compare groups or assess associations; they merely provide data on who, what, when, and where regarding health conditions. Examples include case reports, case series, and cross-sectional studies that describe disease prevalence without testing a specific hypothesis. Incorrect Options: B. Analytical Studies – Incorrect because analytical studies aim to test hypotheses by comparing different groups to establish associations between risk factors and outcomes. Examples include case-control and cohort studies, which are specifically designed to examine causal relationships. C. Case-Control Studies – Incorrect because these are a type of analytical study that compares individuals with a disease (cases) to those without it (controls) to test a hypothesis about potential risk factors. D. Cohort Studies – Incorrect because cohort studies follow groups over time, comparing exposed vs. unexposed individuals to test hypotheses regarding risk factors and disease development.

questions.text: KAP study were first used in India for:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Family Planning KAP (Knowledge, Attitude, and Practice) studies were first used in India for Family Planning programs. The government and researchers used KAP studies to assess public awareness, attitudes, and behaviors regarding contraceptive methods. These studies were essential in designing effective interventions to promote birth control measures and improve reproductive health policies. The findings helped policymakers understand barriers to contraceptive use and implement educational campaigns to increase family planning acceptance. Incorrect Options: A. HIV – Incorrect because while KAP studies have been used extensively in HIV/AIDS research, they were not first introduced for this purpose in India. HIV awareness programs gained prominence much later in the 1980s and 1990s. B. Malaria – Incorrect because malaria control programs in India have relied more on epidemiological surveys and vector control studies rather than KAP studies. Although KAP studies are used to assess knowledge about malaria prevention, they were not the first application in India. D. Ca Cervix (Cervical Cancer) – Incorrect because cervical cancer awareness campaigns gained traction much later, with increased focus on HPV vaccination and screening in recent years. KAP studies in this area are relatively newer compared to family planning

questions.text: In the context of epidemiology - a set of questions is constructed in such a manner that it takes into account all the important epidemiological factors of a given disease :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Epidemiological Surveillance Epidemiological surveillance refers to the systematic collection, analysis, and interpretation of health-related data for planning, implementation, and evaluation of public health programs. In this context, a set of questions is designed to capture all relevant epidemiological factors of a disease, such as its transmission, risk factors, and spread. Surveillance helps in early detection, monitoring, and control of diseases, guiding public health interventions. Incorrect Options: A. Health Model – Incorrect because a health model is a broader conceptual framework used to understand health and disease patterns, but it does not specifically involve constructing targeted epidemiological questions. B. Epidemiological Triad – Incorrect because the epidemiological triad refers to the interaction between agent, host, and environment in disease causation. While it helps understand disease transmission, it does not directly involve designing specific sets of questions for epidemiological studies. D. Mathematical Model – Incorrect because mathematical models use statistical and computational methods to predict disease patterns and outbreaks, but they do not specifically involve question-based data collection.

questions.text: Secular trend is best demonstrated by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Line Diagram A secular trend refers to long-term changes in disease occurrence, health behaviors, or other variables over an extended period (e.g., years or decades). Line diagrams are the best way to demonstrate secular trends because they effectively show continuous data over time, making it easy to visualize upward or downward trends. A line diagram plots data points over a timeline and connects them with lines, making trends clear, interpretable, and easy to compare across different periods. Incorrect Options: B. Bar Graph – Incorrect because bar graphs are better suited for categorical data rather than continuous trends over time. They are used more for comparisons between groups than for visualizing long-term trends. C. Stem-Leaf Plot – Incorrect because a stem-leaf plot is a way of organizing numerical data to show frequency distributions, but it does not effectively illustrate trends over time. D. Box and Whisker Plots – Incorrect because box plots are used to show the distribution, median, quartiles, and outliers of a dataset but are not ideal for demonstrating long-term trends.

questions.text: Epidemiological triad are all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Investigator The epidemiological triad is a fundamental model in epidemiology that explains the interaction between three key factors that contribute to the spread of disease: Host – The organism (human or animal) that can get the disease. Agent – The microorganism (virus, bacteria, parasite, etc.) or factor (chemical, physical, or nutritional) that causes the disease. Environment – External factors (climate, sanitation, social conditions) that affect the interaction between host and agent. The investigator is not a part of the epidemiological triad. The investigator is responsible for studying disease patterns, identifying risk factors, and controlling outbreaks, but does not play a role in disease causation. Incorrect Options: A. Host – Correctly part of the triad. The host is the susceptible individual who can get infected by the agent. B. Environment – Correctly part of the triad. The environment influences disease transmission, including factors like climate, hygiene, and population density. C. Agent – Correctly part of the triad. The agent is the pathogen or cause of the disease, such as bacteria, viruses, toxins, or chemicals.

questions.text: ICD- 11 stands for :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) International Classification of Diseases, 11th revision ICD-11 stands for the International Classification of Diseases, 11th revision. It is a global health reporting tool developed by the World Health Organization (WHO), used for the classification of diseases, conditions, and other health-related problems. The latest version, ICD-11, was adopted by the World Health Assembly in May 2019 and came into effect in January 2022. Incorrect Options: A. International Classification of drugs, 11th revision – This is incorrect. ICD is about diseases and health conditions, not drugs. B. International Classification of Disabilities, 11th revision – This is incorrect. Disabilities are part of the broader classification system, but ICD focuses on diseases and conditions, not disabilities specifically. D. International Classification of Disasters, 11th Revision – This is incorrect. While disasters can affect health, ICD focuses on disease classification and not disaster categorization.

questions.text: Tip of iceberg phenomenon is mostly appropriately represented by :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) PEM (Protein-Energy Malnutrition) The "Tip of the iceberg" phenomenon refers to situations where only a small, visible portion of a problem is seen, while the majority of it is hidden or unreported. In the case of Protein-Energy Malnutrition (PEM), the visible symptoms often represent only the tip of the iceberg. Many cases of PEM may go undiagnosed or untreated, especially in its less severe forms, such as stunted growth or subtle nutritional deficiencies, which are often not immediately visible. The visible cases of PEM, like severe wasting or kwashiorkor, represent the most severe manifestations, but the larger number of individuals suffering from milder forms of malnutrition are often overlooked. Incorrect Options: A. Malaria – Malaria is a well-diagnosed and widely recognized disease, and the symptoms are usually fairly visible. The "tip of the iceberg" concept doesn't apply as strongly to malaria because most cases, if properly diagnosed, can be treated. B. Measles – Measles cases are generally reported when they occur, and the disease is well understood. While there are some underreported cases, the "tip of the iceberg" phenomenon does not fully capture the epidemiology of measles. D. Rabies – Rabies is a disease that often leads to death once symptoms appear. The "tip of the iceberg" concept is less applicable because rabies cases are relatively easy to identify in the final stages (once neurological symptoms manifest), though the number of unreported rabies cases is limited.

questions.text: Intraspecies competition is the competition among:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Individuals of a population Intraspecies competition refers to competition that occurs among individuals of the same species within a population. This type of competition happens when individuals vie for the same limited resources, such as food, shelter, mates, or territory. The competition can influence survival rates, reproduction, and overall fitness within the population. Incorrect Options: A. Species – This would refer to interspecies competition, which is competition between different species, not within the same species. Interspecies competition involves different species competing for the same resources but is distinct from intraspecies competition. C. Individuals of a community – A community refers to a group of different species living together in a given area. Intraspecies competition happens within a single species, not among individuals from different species of a community. D. Populations and their regulatory factors – This option is related to population regulation, which refers to the factors that control the size and growth of populations. These factors include predation, disease, and resource availability but are not specifically about competition within a species.

choices.text: Is a form of direct standardization
Is calculated as Observed deaths/Expected deaths x 100
Can be used for disease as event of occurrence

questions.text: All are true for Standardized Mortality ratio (SMR) except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) "Is a form of direct standardization." The Standardized Mortality Ratio (SMR) is not a form of direct standardization. It is a ratio that compares the observed number of deaths in a study population with the expected number of deaths based on the age-specific rates from a standard population. The SMR is used to assess whether the mortality in a study population is higher or lower than would be expected based on a reference population. It does not involve direct standardization but is a comparison to a standard. Incorrect responses: (B) "Is calculated as Observed deaths/Expected deaths x 100": This is correct. The SMR is calculated by dividing the observed number of deaths by the expected number of deaths (based on the standard population) and multiplying by 100 to get a percentage. An SMR of 100 means the observed deaths are equal to the expected deaths. (C) "Permits adjustment for age": This is true. SMR is often used to adjust for age differences between populations. By comparing the observed mortality rate to an age-adjusted expected rate, it helps to eliminate age as a confounding factor in the comparison. (D) "Can be used for disease as event of occurrence": This statement is true as well. While SMR is primarily used for mortality rates, it can also be applied to other events, like disease incidence, when comparing observed to expected cases.

choices.text: Age specific death rates of standard population is necessary
Age specific death rates of study population is necessary

questions.text: About direct standardization all are true except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) "Age specific death rates of standard population is necessary." In direct standardization, age-specific death rates of the study population are necessary, but age-specific death rates of the standard population are not used in the standardization process. The purpose of direct standardization is to apply the age-specific death rates of the study population to a standard population to calculate the expected number of deaths for each age group. This allows for a comparison between the study population and the standard population. The standard population is used as a reference, but its age-specific death rates are not needed for the study population's direct standardization. Incorrect responses: (B) "A standard population is needed": This is true. Direct standardization involves using a standard population for comparison purposes. The standard population can be a national population, a population from a different region, or any other population with known age structure. (C) "Age specific death rates of study population is necessary": This is true. For direct standardization, age-specific death rates from the study population are essential. These rates are applied to the standard population to calculate the expected number of deaths. (D) "Two populations are compared": This is true. Direct standardization involves comparing the study population with the standard population. The rates of the study population are standardized to the age distribution of the standard population to adjust for differences in age structure.

questions.text: The rate adjusted to allow for the age distribution of the population is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Age-standardized mortality rate. The Age-standardized mortality rate (ASMR) is a measure used to adjust the crude mortality rate for the age distribution of a population. It allows comparisons of mortality rates between populations that may have different age structures. By adjusting for age, it ensures that the comparison between populations is not biased by differences in their age distributions. For instance, a population with a larger proportion of elderly individuals may have a higher crude mortality rate due to the natural increase in mortality with age. Age-standardization removes this effect, providing a more accurate comparison between different populations or over time. Incorrect responses: (A) Peri-natal mortality rate: This is a measure of the number of stillbirths and deaths of infants within the first week of life per 1,000 live births. It does not adjust for age distribution. (B) Crude mortality rate: The crude mortality rate is the total number of deaths in a population, divided by the total population size, without adjusting for age. It is a general measure that does not take into account the age structure of the population. (C) Fertility rate: The fertility rate measures the number of live births in a population over a specific period, often per 1,000 women of reproductive age. It is unrelated to mortality and does not adjust for age.

questions.text: What is best in order to make a comparison between two same populations?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Standardized mortality rate When comparing the overall mortality experience within the same population at different points in time, or under different interventions, the Standardized Mortality Rate (SMR) is often the best measure for a fair comparison, especially if there have been changes in the age structure of that population over the comparison period. Even within a single population, its age distribution can shift due to birth rates, migration, or aging. If the population has aged over time, its crude death rate might appear to increase simply because there are more older individuals, even if age-specific risks haven't changed. By standardizing, we adjust for these demographic shifts, allowing for an "apples-to-apples" comparison of the underlying risk of death independent of changes in age composition. This provides a more accurate picture of whether the population's overall health has genuinely improved or worsened, or if an intervention has had a real effect, rather than just reflecting demographic shifts. Incorrect Responses: B. Disease-specific death rate: While highly valuable, the disease-specific death rate tells us about mortality from a particular disease (e.g., heart disease, cancer). It's the best measure if your goal is to compare how the burden of a single, specific disease has changed within the same population over time. However, it does not provide an overall comparison of the entire mortality experience, encompassing all causes of death. Therefore, it's not the "best" for a general "overall mortality experience" comparison. C. Proportional mortality rate (PMR): The proportional mortality rate indicates the percentage of all deaths attributed to a specific cause within the population. For instance, "What proportion of deaths were due to stroke in 2000 vs. 2020?" While it shows shifts in the relative importance of different causes of death, it is not suitable for comparing the absolute risk of death or the overall mortality burden. A change in the PMR for one cause can be influenced by changes in the number of deaths from other causes, rather than a true change in the risk for that specific cause. D. Age-specific death rate: Age-specific death rates provide detailed information on mortality within distinct age groups (e.g., deaths per 1,000 individuals aged 40-49). These rates are crucial for understanding which age groups are most affected and how risks change across the lifespan. However, when aiming for a single, summary comparison of the overall mortality experience for the entire population over time, relying solely on a multitude of individual age-specific rates can be cumbersome. While essential for constructing standardized rates, age-specific rates themselves don't provide a single, summary measure that accounts for the potential shift in the overall age structure of the population.

choices.text: Standardization allows comparison to be made between 2 different populations
National population is always taken as the standard population
For direct Standardization, age specific rates of study population are applied to that of standard population
For Indirect Standardization age specific rates of standard population are applied to study population

questions.text: All the statements are true about standardization except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) National population is always taken as the standard population. (A) Standardization allows comparison to be made between 2 different populations: This statement is true. Standardization helps adjust for differences in population characteristics, such as age distribution, so that more meaningful comparisons can be made between two populations. (B) National population is always taken as the standard population: This statement is false. While national population data can be used as a standard in some cases, it is not always the case. A standard population can be any population chosen for comparison, and it doesn’t have to be the national population. In practice, different standard populations can be used depending on the study’s needs (for example, a global standard population or a population from a similar demographic group). (C) For direct Standardization, age-specific rates of study population are applied to that of standard population: This statement is true. In direct standardization, the age-specific rates from the study population are applied to the age distribution of the standard population. This allows for an adjusted rate that is independent of the age structure of the study population. (D) For Indirect Standardization, age-specific rates of standard population are applied to study population: This statement is true. In indirect standardization, the age-specific rates of the standard population are applied to the age distribution of the study population to obtain an expected number of events (e.g., deaths) in the study population.

questions.text: At what point in time is the population assessed for calculation of the crude death rate?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 1st July. Crude Death Rate (CDR) is usually calculated based on the population at the midpoint of the year, which is 1st July. This is because the population is assessed at a time that reflects the average size for the entire year, considering factors like births, deaths, and migration. Using the midpoint allows for a more accurate representation of the population over the year, as compared to taking a snapshot at the beginning or end of the year. Incorrect options: (A) 1st Jan: The population on 1st January is used to start the year, but it doesn't account for the changes in population size that happen during the year, such as births and deaths occurring after January. Thus, it's not ideal for a more accurate reflection of the population during the year. (B) 1st May: Using the population on 1st May would be less accurate than using the midpoint of the year. It doesn't provide a comprehensive view of the average population for the entire year, which is important for demographic calculations. (D) 31st Dec: While 31st December provides a snapshot of the population at the end of the year, it doesn't account for the fluctuation in population size throughout the year. It also ignores the earlier months of the year when changes in the population might have occurred.

questions.text: All are indicators of mortality except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Duration of sickness. The Duration of sickness is not a direct indicator of mortality. It refers to how long an individual suffers from a particular illness or condition, but it doesn't measure death or the risk of dying from a disease. Mortality indicators are typically concerned with the occurrence of death, such as how many people die from a particular condition or within a given population over a specific period. Incorrect options: (A) Case fatality rate: This is an important mortality indicator. It measures the proportion of individuals who die from a specific disease among those who are diagnosed with it. It provides insight into the severity and lethality of a particular disease. (B) Life expectancy: Life expectancy is a key measure of mortality, indicating the average number of years a person can expect to live based on current death rates. It is a broad indicator of overall mortality in a population. (D) Standardized death rate: This is also an indicator of mortality. It adjusts the crude death rate to account for differences in age distribution between populations, allowing for a more accurate comparison of death rates across different groups.

questions.text: Following can be used as a yardstick for the assessment of standards of therapy:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Survival rate. The Survival rate is used as a yardstick for assessing the standards of therapy. It measures the percentage of patients who survive a disease or condition for a specified period after diagnosis or treatment. High survival rates typically indicate effective treatment or therapy standards, making it a direct measure of therapeutic success and effectiveness in medical practice. Incorrect options: (A) Specific death rate: This refers to the death rate from a specific cause in a defined population, adjusted for certain factors such as age or sex. It’s more of an indicator of mortality in a population rather than a measure of therapy effectiveness. (B) Case fatality rate: While the case fatality rate measures the proportion of people who die from a specific disease out of those diagnosed, it does not directly measure therapy standards. It focuses more on the severity of the disease and the outcome rather than the effectiveness of treatment. (C) Proportional mortality rate: This is the percentage of deaths from a specific cause relative to the total number of deaths in a population. It provides insight into disease burden but does not assess the quality of therapy provided.

questions.text: In an outbreak of cholera in a village of 200 population 20 cases have occurred and 5 have died. Case fatality rate is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 25%. The Case Fatality Rate (CFR) is calculated by the formula: CFR= (Number of deaths from the disease/Number of confirmed cases of the disease) x 100 In this case: Number of deaths = 5 Number of cases = 20 CFR=(5/20) x 100 = 25% Thus, the case fatality rate is 25%, which means 25% of the people who contracted cholera in this village died from the disease. Incorrect options: • (A) 1%: This is too low for the given data. The number of deaths is 5 out of 20 cases, which leads to a much higher CFR. • (B) 0.25%: This is incorrect because it does not match the calculation, as the number of deaths and cases are much higher than what would result in this rate. • (C) 5%: This is incorrect because the calculation of the CFR is much higher (25%) based on the given data.

questions.text: Which one of the following is a better indicator of the severity of an acute disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Case Fatality Rate. The Case Fatality Rate (CFR) is the proportion of individuals diagnosed with a specific disease who die from that disease within a certain period of time. It is an important indicator of the severity of an acute disease because it directly measures the severity of the disease and the likelihood of death among those who are affected by it. CFR=(Number of deaths from the disease/Number of diagnosed cases) x 100 A high CFR indicates that the disease is more severe and that a larger proportion of those affected are dying from it. Incorrect options: (A) Cause specific death rate: This is a general measure of the number of deaths due to a specific cause in a population over a specific period. While it helps in understanding the burden of disease, it does not directly measure the severity of the disease itself as effectively as the CFR. (C) Standardized mortality ratio: This is used to compare the mortality rate of a population to the expected mortality rate based on a standard population, often accounting for age differences. While it is useful for population comparisons, it does not directly reflect the severity of an individual disease. (D) Five-year survival rate: This is used to assess the prognosis of chronic diseases or cancers over a longer period of time. It is not the best indicator for acute diseases, where immediate severity is more relevant.

choices.text: It may vary from the same disease in different epidemics
It is useful in chronic diseases

questions.text: Which one is not true of case fatality rate?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) It is useful in chronic diseases. The Case Fatality Rate (CFR) is the proportion of individuals diagnosed with a specific disease who die from that disease within a specific period. The CFR is particularly useful for assessing the severity of acute diseases, where the time frame for death following diagnosis is relatively short. It helps to understand how lethal a disease is in the population of affected individuals. It is useful in chronic diseases: CFR is typically not useful for chronic diseases because these diseases are often long-term, and death may occur years after diagnosis, making it less practical for assessing the immediate severity of the disease. Chronic diseases have other measures, like survival rate or morbidity rate, that are more appropriate for understanding the long-term impact. The other options are true regarding CFR: (A) It is a proportion: CFR is a ratio, or proportion, which expresses the number of deaths from a particular disease among all those diagnosed with the disease. It is calculated as the number of deaths divided by the number of diagnosed cases. (B) Time interval is non-specified: Although the CFR often refers to a specific period (e.g., during an outbreak), the time interval can vary depending on the disease and how the CFR is being assessed. It is not always strictly defined unless the context specifies it. (C) It may vary from the same disease in different epidemics: The CFR can vary between different epidemics due to factors such as differences in healthcare systems, access to treatment, population demographics, and the virulence of the disease.

questions.text: The usefulness for “Case Fatality Rate” is very limited in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Chronic illness. Case Fatality Rate (CFR) is a measure used to assess the severity of an illness by calculating the proportion of people who die from a specific disease out of those diagnosed with it, within a defined time period. This measure is typically more useful for acute illnesses that cause death in a relatively short time frame after diagnosis. For chronic illnesses, CFR is less useful because: Chronic diseases, such as heart disease, diabetes, or cancer, tend to have a long course, with death occurring years or even decades after the initial diagnosis. This makes it challenging to accurately assess severity or predict outcomes using CFR within a short time frame. Chronic diseases often have multiple complications, and death is not directly tied to the disease itself in the same way it is for acute diseases. The process of dying from chronic illness is often more gradual and multifactorial, making CFR less of a practical or accurate measure. On the other hand: (A) Sub-acute illness: CFR can be useful for sub-acute illnesses, which have a somewhat extended time course but are still more time-limited compared to chronic conditions. (B) Acute illness: CFR is highly useful for acute illnesses because the death typically occurs in the short term following the onset of symptoms, making it easier to measure the direct lethality of the disease.

choices.text: Killing power of a disease in a time
Killing power of a disease with no time interval

questions.text: Case fatality rate is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Killing power of a disease with no time interval. Case Fatality Rate (CFR) refers to the proportion of people who die from a specific disease out of those diagnosed with it, usually calculated over the course of an outbreak or a certain period of time. It reflects the killing power of a disease but is distinct because the time frame is not always specifically defined and can vary based on the disease. The time interval may not always be fixed or clearly defined, and CFR can be used in both short- and long-term contexts. Therefore, CFR is associated with the killing power of a disease in general, regardless of the specific time interval. Incorrect answers: (A) Spreading power of a disease: This is incorrect because the spreading power of a disease is typically referred to as transmissibility or contagiousness (how easily the disease spreads among individuals or populations). Case Fatality Rate, on the other hand, does not measure how the disease spreads but instead how lethal it is for those who get it. (B) Killing power of a disease in a time: While CFR does refer to the killing power of a disease, it is not limited to a specific time interval. The time frame is not fixed in all cases, and it can be assessed over varying durations depending on the context. Therefore, CFR is not always calculated in a specified time period. (D) Resistance of disease: This is incorrect because resistance refers to the ability of a population or individual to resist a disease or infection, typically through immunity or other factors. Case Fatality Rate measures the proportion of people who die from the disease, not the resistance of the disease or host.

questions.text: Estimating the burden of particular disease in a community is measured by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Proportional mortality rate The Proportional Mortality Rate (PMR) is used to estimate the burden of a particular disease in a community by measuring the proportion of all deaths attributed to that disease. It is a ratio that compares the number of deaths from a specific disease to the total number of deaths from all causes in a given population. By expressing the burden of the disease in terms of the total number of deaths, it provides insight into how much of the overall mortality is due to that specific disease, helping in understanding the impact or burden of that disease in the community. Incorrect answers: (B) Disease specific mortality: Disease specific mortality refers to the number of deaths from a particular disease within a specific period, but it doesn't provide a relative measure compared to all other causes of death. It is more focused on the absolute number rather than the proportion, which makes it less effective in estimating the burden of disease compared to the proportional mortality rate. (C) Crude death rate: The crude death rate is the total number of deaths in a population over a specified period of time, typically expressed per 1,000 individuals. It does not account for specific causes of death or the burden of a particular disease, and therefore, it is not a useful indicator for measuring the burden of a specific disease in a community. (D) Incidence of disease: Incidence measures the number of new cases of a disease in a population over a specific time period. While it is important for understanding the frequency of new cases, it does not directly assess the burden in terms of mortality, making it less applicable for measuring disease burden through death rates.

questions.text: Proportional mortality rate is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Proportion Explanation for correct answer: The Proportional Mortality Rate (PMR) is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. It is calculated by dividing the number of deaths from a specific cause by the total number of deaths in a population during a certain time period. This gives the proportion of deaths due to a specific disease out of all deaths, expressing the disease’s contribution to overall mortality. Since the result is a proportion, it is typically expressed as a percentage or a decimal. Incorrect answers: (A) Rate: A rate involves the occurrence of an event (like death) over time in a population. PMR is not a rate because it does not involve time in the denominator. It simply measures the proportion of deaths from a specific cause in a given period. (B) Ratio: A ratio compares two different quantities. The PMR is not a ratio because both the numerator (deaths from a specific cause) and the denominator (total deaths) are of the same kind, making it a proportion rather than a ratio. (D) None: Since the PMR is indeed a proportion, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Denominator for calculating proportional mortality rate from a specific disease is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Total deaths in that year The denominator for calculating the Proportional Mortality Rate (PMR) is the total deaths that occur in a population during the specific time period (usually a year). PMR is calculated by dividing the number of deaths from a specific cause by the total number of deaths, then multiplying by 100 or expressing it as a percentage. This gives an indication of the proportion of all deaths attributable to a specific cause. Incorrect answers: (A) Mid year population during that year: This is used for calculating other rates like crude death rate (CDR) or mortality rates, but not for proportional mortality rate. PMR is concerned with the number of deaths, not the population size. (B) Population at risk in that particular area: This would apply in cases where we are considering the risk of disease or death in a population, but for PMR, we are focusing on deaths, not the entire population at risk. (D) Attributable deaths of a particular disease: This refers to the number of deaths directly caused by a specific disease, but the denominator for PMR is the total number of deaths in the population, not just those attributed to the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is not true ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Effective treatment modalities for non-communicable diseases will decrease incidence Option (D) is incorrect because effective treatment for non-communicable diseases (NCDs) generally does not reduce the incidence of these diseases. Incidence refers to the number of new cases of a disease in a specific period, and treatment does not prevent new cases from occurring. For example, the treatment of diabetes or hypertension does not prevent new individuals from developing these conditions; it only helps manage symptoms or complications in those already affected. Explanation for other options: (A) Incidence decreases when a programme is effective: This is true. When a public health program (like vaccination or preventive screening) is effective, it can reduce the number of new cases of a disease, leading to a decrease in incidence. (B) Incidence implies number of new cases detected over a fixed time: This is also correct. Incidence is the measure of the number of new cases of a disease in a specific population over a certain period of time, providing insight into the rate at which new cases develop. (C) Vaccination strategies decrease the incidence of a disease: This is true. Vaccination programs help prevent new cases of infectious diseases by immunizing individuals before they are exposed to the pathogen, thereby reducing the overall incidence in the population.

questions.text: If a new effective treatment for cancer is initiated and all factor remain same , which of the following is most likely to happen.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Incidence will not change The introduction of a new effective treatment for cancer is likely to affect the prevalence of the disease (the number of existing cases) rather than the incidence (the number of new cases). Incidence measures new cases of cancer, and the availability of a treatment does not change the occurrence of new cancer cases in a population. It only helps manage or prolong the lives of those already diagnosed, which can increase the prevalence. Incorrect Options: (B) Prevalence will not change: This is incorrect. The introduction of an effective treatment is likely to prolong the lives of individuals with cancer, thus increasing the prevalence of the disease (i.e., more people will be living with the disease at a given time). (C) Neither will change: This is incorrect because the new treatment will most likely impact the prevalence of cancer, even if the incidence remains unchanged. (D) Incidence and prevalence will change: This is incorrect because while the new treatment may influence the prevalence by prolonging life, it is not expected to directly affect the incidence (the rate of new cases).

questions.text: A diagnostic test has been introduced that will detect a certain disease 1 yrs earlier than it is usually detected. Which of the following is most likely to happen to the disease within the 10 yrs after the test its introduced? (Assumed that early detection has no effect on the natural history of the disease. Also assume that no changes in death certification practices occur during the 10yrs.):
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The apparent 5-year survival rate will increase Explanation for correct answer: When a diagnostic test is introduced that detects a disease one year earlier than it would typically be detected, it identifies cases at an earlier stage. Since survival rates are often calculated based on how long a person survives after diagnosis, detecting the disease earlier will artificially increase the apparent 5-year survival rate, even though the natural history of the disease hasn't changed. The person would be diagnosed earlier, and their survival time from diagnosis would appear longer, even though the actual course of the disease remains the same. Incorrect Options: (A) The period prevalence rate will decrease: This is incorrect. Early detection actually increases the period prevalence rate, as more people are diagnosed during the time period. Period prevalence refers to the number of people who have the disease at any point during a specific period. With earlier detection, more individuals will be diagnosed, which increases prevalence, not decreases it. (C) The age-adjusted mortality rate will decrease: This is incorrect. Since the early detection doesn't change the actual outcome (death), and mortality rates are based on deaths, the mortality rate will likely remain unaffected by the earlier diagnosis, assuming death certification practices and other factors remain unchanged. (D) The incidence rate will decrease: This is incorrect. The incidence rate refers to the number of new cases of a disease in a population. Early detection doesn't affect how many new cases occur; it just detects them earlier, so the incidence rate remains the same.

questions.text: If the prevalence is very low as compared to the incidence for adisease, it implies:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Disease is very fatal and/or easily curable Explanation for correct answer: If the prevalence of a disease is very low compared to its incidence, it generally suggests that the disease has a high mortality rate (it is fatal) or it has a high cure rate, leading to a short duration of illness. This means that even though new cases (incidence) are occurring at a relatively high rate, people either die or recover quickly, which prevents a large number of people from remaining sick long enough to increase the prevalence. Incorrect Options: (B) Disease is non-fatal: This is incorrect. A non-fatal disease typically has a higher prevalence compared to incidence, as people can live with the disease for a long time without dying or being cured. A low prevalence relative to incidence usually suggests something about the fatality or curability of the disease, not its non-fatal nature. (C) Calculation of prevalence & incidence is wrong: This is incorrect. The situation described here is a legitimate epidemiological observation. It can occur when a disease has a very high fatality rate or is easily curable, so the calculation methods themselves are not wrong. (D) Nothing can be said, as they are independent: This is incorrect. Prevalence and incidence are related, as prevalence is influenced by both the rate of new cases (incidence) and the duration of the disease (which can be affected by fatality and cure rates). The relationship between the two provides important information about the disease dynamics.

questions.text: Prevalence of a disease all are true except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Is the number of new cases in a defined population Explanation for correct answer: Prevalence refers to the total number of cases (both new and existing) of a particular disease in a population at a specific point in time or over a specific period. It is not limited to just new cases; it includes all cases, whether newly diagnosed or ongoing. Therefore, stating that prevalence is "the number of new cases" is incorrect, as this description aligns more with the concept of incidence. Incorrect Options: (A) Is the best measure of disease burden in etiological studies: This is incorrect. Prevalence is a useful measure of disease burden at a particular point in time, but it is not the best measure for etiological studies. Incidence and the study of risk factors (which are better assessed by cohort studies or case-control studies) are often more informative when investigating the cause of a disease. (B) Can only be determined by a cross-sectional study: This is true. Prevalence is typically assessed through cross-sectional studies, where data is collected at a single point in time. This allows for the identification of how many individuals currently have the disease, including both new and existing cases. (D) Describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery: This is true. Prevalence reflects the balance between the rate of new cases (incidence), the number of deaths (mortality), and recoveries or cures. If incidence is high and recovery or mortality is low, prevalence will increase, and vice versa.

questions.text: The relationship between incidence and prevalence can be expresses as:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The product of incidence and mean duration of disease The relationship between incidence and prevalence is typically represented by the equation: Prevalence=Incidence × Mean Duration of Disease This means that prevalence is determined by both the rate of new cases (incidence) and the length of time people live with the disease. If a disease has a high incidence but a short duration (due to quick recovery or high mortality), prevalence will be low. Conversely, if a disease has a low incidence but a long duration (such as chronic illnesses like diabetes), prevalence will be high. For example, in chronic diseases like hypertension or diabetes, the incidence may not be extremely high, but because patients live with the disease for a long time, prevalence remains high. In contrast, for an acute illness like influenza, incidence may be high during an outbreak, but since most people recover quickly, prevalence remains low. Incorrect Options: (B) The dividend of incidence and mean duration of disease: This is incorrect because dividing incidence by the duration of the disease does not provide a meaningful measure of prevalence. Instead, prevalence is the total burden of disease in a population, which is influenced by how frequently new cases arise (incidence) and how long people remain affected. (C) The sum of incidence and mean duration of disease: Prevalence is not obtained by adding incidence and mean duration of disease. These are two different measures; incidence represents new cases, while duration refers to the length of time a person remains ill. Adding them together does not logically reflect the disease burden in a population. (D) The difference of incidence and mean duration of disease: Subtracting mean duration from incidence has no epidemiological significance. Prevalence depends on both factors working together, not as a difference. The concept of disease burden is better captured through multiplication, which accounts for both new cases and the persistence of the disease over time.

questions.text: Prevalence of cataract at the one point of time can be determined by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cross-sectional study A cross-sectional study is the best method to determine the prevalence of cataract at a single point in time. Prevalence refers to the total number of cases (both new and existing) of a disease in a given population at a specific moment. A cross-sectional study collects data at a single point in time, making it ideal for measuring the burden of a condition like cataract in a population. For example, if we conduct an eye screening survey in a community and record the number of individuals diagnosed with cataracts at that moment, we are measuring point prevalence using a cross-sectional study. This method is widely used in public health and epidemiology to assess disease burden and plan healthcare interventions. Incorrect Options: (A) Longitudinal study: Longitudinal studies follow the same individuals over a period of time, collecting data at multiple time points. While they are useful for studying incidence (new cases) and disease progression, they are not ideal for measuring prevalence at a single point in time. (C) Surveillance: Surveillance refers to ongoing, systematic data collection for monitoring and controlling diseases over time. While it provides useful information on disease trends, it is not the preferred method for determining prevalence at a specific point. (D) Cohort study: A cohort study follows a group of people over time to assess risk factors and incidence rates of a disease. It is useful for understanding how cataracts develop but is not designed to measure prevalence at a single point in time.

questions.text: All about incidence are false except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Not affected by duration Incidence refers to the number of new cases of a disease occurring in a defined population over a specific period of time. It is independent of the duration of the disease because it only considers new cases and does not account for how long the disease lasts. For example, if 100 new cases of diabetes are diagnosed in a population of 10,000 over a year, the incidence rate is calculated based on those 100 cases, regardless of whether they last for years or resolve quickly. This distinguishes incidence from prevalence, which includes both new and existing cases and is influenced by disease duration. Incorrect Options: (B) More than prevalence: This is false because prevalence includes both new and existing cases, while incidence only includes new cases. If a disease has a long duration (e.g., diabetes), its prevalence is usually higher than its incidence. However, for short-duration diseases with rapid recovery or death (e.g., Ebola), incidence may be closer to prevalence. (C) Measures old and new cases: This is false because incidence only measures new cases. Prevalence, on the other hand, includes both new and old cases at a given point in time. (D) Used for chronic conditions: This is false because incidence is generally used to study acute conditions and disease occurrence over time. For chronic diseases (e.g., hypertension or diabetes), prevalence is a more useful measure since these diseases persist for a long duration.

questions.text: Incidence rate is calculated from:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Prospective Study Incidence rate is the measure of new cases of a disease occurring in a population over a specific period of time. To accurately calculate incidence, we need to follow a population over time and count the number of new cases that develop. Prospective studies are designed to do exactly this by following a disease-free population into the future and recording the occurrence of new cases. For example, in a cohort study, a group of initially healthy individuals is monitored over time to track the development of a disease, making it the best study design for calculating incidence rate. Incorrect Options: (A) Case-Control Study: This is false because case-control studies are retrospective and focus on individuals who already have the disease (cases) and those who do not (controls). Since these studies start with people who already have the disease, they cannot measure the incidence of new cases. Instead, they estimate the association between exposure and disease using odds ratios. (C) Retrospective Study: This is false because retrospective studies look backward in time, using existing records to examine past exposure and disease occurrence. They are not designed to track new cases over time, making them unsuitable for calculating incidence. (D) Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT): This is false because RCTs are experimental studies that compare treatment effects between groups. Although they follow participants over time, their primary aim is not to measure incidence but rather to determine the effectiveness of interventions.

questions.text: The following is true about prevalence and incidence:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Incidence is a rate but prevalence is not Incidence is a measure of the number of new cases of a disease occurring in a specific population over a defined period of time. It is expressed as a rate because it includes a time component, making it a measure of risk. Prevalence, on the other hand, represents the total number of cases (both new and existing) in a population at a given point in time or over a period. It is expressed as a proportion (not a rate) since it does not measure how quickly new cases are occurring. Thus, incidence is a rate, while prevalence is a proportion, making option (C) the correct answer. Incorrect Options: (A) Both are rates – False Prevalence is not a rate because it does not account for time. It simply measures the proportion of people affected by a disease at a specific time. (B) Prevalence is a rate but incidence is not – False Incidence is the true rate because it measures how fast new cases develop over time, while prevalence is a proportion. (D) Both are not rates – False Incidence is a rate, while prevalence is a proportion, so this statement is incorrect.

questions.text: A district has total population 10 lakhs, with under- 16 population being 30%. The prevalence of blindness is 0.8/1000 among under- 16 population. Calculate total number of blind among under- 16 population in the district
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 240, as it is derived using the correct method of calculating the total number of blind individuals in the under-16 population. We are given: • Total population = 10,00,000 (10 lakhs) • Under-16 population = 30% of total population • Prevalence of blindness in under-16 = 0.8 per 1000 Step 1: Calculate Under-16 Population Under-16 Population=30% × 10,00,000 = 30/100 x 1000000 = 300000 Step 2: Calculate Number of Blind Cases The prevalence rate tells us that 0.8 out of every 1000 individuals in this group are blind. So, applying this rate to the total under-16 population: Total Blind in Under-16 Population = 0.8/1000 x 300000 = 0.8 x 300 = 240 Incorrect Options Explained: Option (B) 2400 This would be the answer if the prevalence rate were 8 per 1000 instead of 0.8 per 1000. Incorrect because the given prevalence rate is 0.8 per 1000, not 8 per 1000. Option (C) 24,000 This would be the answer if prevalence was incorrectly assumed as 8 per 100 instead of 0.8 per 1000. Incorrect because the prevalence rate is much lower. Option (D) 2,40,000 This would imply that 80% of the under-16 population is blind, which is unrealistic. Incorrect because it is a miscalculation of prevalence and total population.

questions.text: In a town of population 5000, 500 are already myopic on January 1, 2011, Number of new myopia cases is 90 till December 31, 2011. Calculate incidence of Myopia in the town in 2011.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 0.02. Incidence is calculated as the number of new cases of a disease in a specific period divided by the population at risk at the beginning of that period. Given Data: Total population = 5000 Already myopic cases on January 1, 2011 = 500 New myopia cases in 2011 = 90 Step 1: Calculate Population at Risk Since 500 individuals are already myopic, they are not at risk of developing new myopia. So, the population at risk = Total population - Existing myopic cases =5000-500=4500 Step 2: Calculate Incidence Rate Incidence rate is given by: Incidence= New Cases / Population Risk = 90/4500 =0.02 (or 2 per 100 individuals) Incorrect Options Explained: Option (A) 0.018 This value would be correct if the denominator were slightly higher, but it incorrectly assumes a different population at risk. The correct denominator is 4500, making 0.02 the correct value. Option (C) 0.05 This would mean a much higher incidence, implying that 225 new cases developed, which is incorrect. Here, the number of new cases is only 90, so the incidence is lower. Option (D) 18 This is incorrectly calculated and does not follow the standard formula for incidence. Incidence is always expressed as a proportion (or percentage), not an absolute number.

questions.text: In population of 5000 number of new cases of TB is 500 old cases in the same population are 150. What is the prevalence of TB?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 13%. Prevalence is the total number of cases (both new and old) of a disease in a population at a given time, divided by the total population. Given Data: Total Population = 5000 New Cases of TB = 500 Old Cases of TB = 150 Step 1: Calculate Total Cases of TB Total TB cases=New cases + Old cases =500+150=650 Prevalence=(Total cases / Total Population) x 100 = (650/5000) x 100 = 13% Incorrect Options Explained: Option (A) 9% This would imply that only 450 cases exist, which is incorrect since the actual total cases are 650. Option (B) 12% A 12% prevalence would correspond to 600 cases, which is less than the actual total of 650. Option (D) 18% An 18% prevalence would mean 900 cases, which exceeds the total cases given in the question.

questions.text: When the prevalence rate is used without any qualification it is taken to mean as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Point Prevalence. Prevalence, when mentioned without any specific time qualification, refers to point prevalence. Point prevalence is the proportion of individuals in a population who have a specific disease or condition at a single point in time. This is the most common interpretation when the term "prevalence rate" is used without additional context or time frames. Incorrect Options Explained: Option (B) Period Prevalence Rate Period prevalence is the proportion of individuals with a disease over a defined period of time (e.g., a year). While it accounts for the disease presence over time, it is not the default interpretation when no time period is specified. Option (C) Annual Prevalence Rate Annual prevalence is also a form of period prevalence but refers to the disease burden over a year. The term "annual" isn't the default for "prevalence rate" unless specified. Option (D) Mean Duration Prevalence Rate This is not a standard term in epidemiology. Although disease duration can influence prevalence, "mean duration prevalence rate" is not used to describe general prevalence in the absence of qualification.

questions.text: A drug which reduces mortality but does not cure a disease will gradually lead to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Incidence same, prevalence increases. A drug that reduces mortality but does not cure the disease will not affect the number of new cases (incidence) of the disease, as the incidence is a measure of new occurrences. However, it will allow those who already have the disease to live longer, leading to an increase in the number of people living with the disease at any given time. This will cause the prevalence (the total number of existing cases) to increase, as more individuals will be surviving with the condition. The incidence remains the same because the number of new cases is not altered by the drug's ability to reduce mortality. Incorrect Options: A. Incidence and prevalence both increase: This option is incorrect because while the drug reduces mortality, it does not prevent new cases from emerging. Therefore, the incidence will remain unchanged, not increase. Prevalence may increase, but incidence is unaffected. B. Incidence and prevalence both decrease: This is incorrect because while the drug reduces mortality, it doesn't have any effect on the occurrence of new cases (incidence), so it cannot cause the incidence to decrease. Prevalence may increase due to longer survival, not decrease. C. Incidence increase, prevalence decrease: This option is also incorrect. The drug does not affect the rate of new cases (incidence), so the incidence cannot increase. Additionally, the drug increases survival without curing the disease, meaning more people will live with the disease, leading to an increase in prevalence rather than a decrease.

questions.text: High prevalence associated with:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Longer duration of disease. High prevalence of a disease is primarily associated with the longer duration of the disease. When individuals live longer with the disease—whether due to slower progression, better management, or effective treatment to reduce mortality—more people are living with the condition at any given time. This increases the total number of cases, thereby raising the prevalence. The duration of disease plays a significant role in determining prevalence, as the longer individuals have the disease, the higher the prevalence. Incorrect Options: A. High Cure rate: A high cure rate would generally lead to a reduction in prevalence, not an increase, because more individuals would recover and no longer be counted as cases of the disease. High cure rates would therefore lower the total number of people living with the disease. B. Immigration of healthy people: While immigration of healthy people could increase the population size, it doesn't directly affect the prevalence of the disease unless the immigrants are at risk of developing it. In this case, the presence of healthy individuals does not contribute directly to the prevalence of disease unless they contract it, so this option is incorrect. D. Less Incidence of disease: Lower incidence (fewer new cases) would typically lead to a decrease in prevalence over time, not an increase. Prevalence is a combination of new cases (incidence) and people living with the disease. A lower incidence without a corresponding increase in mortality might eventually reduce prevalence, rather than increase it.

questions.text: Incidence of a disease in a population of 30,000 and 300 new cases is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 10 per 1000. The incidence of a disease is calculated by dividing the number of new cases by the total population at risk, and then multiplying the result by 1000 to express it per 1000 individuals. In this case, there are 300 new cases in a population of 30,000 people. The formula would be: Incidence = (New Cases/Population Risk) x 1000 = (300/30000) x 1000 = 10 per 1000 Incorrect Options: • A. 0.1 per 1000: This option is incorrect. If the incidence were 0.1 per 1000, it would mean there were only 3 new cases in a population of 30,000, which is far lower than the given 300 new cases. This option underestimates the actual incidence rate. • C. 100 per 1000: This is also incorrect. A rate of 100 per 1000 would suggest 3,000 new cases in a population of 30,000, which is far higher than the actual 300 new cases provided in the question. This overestimates the incidence rate. • D. 1 per 1000: This is incorrect as well. A rate of 1 per 1000 would suggest there were only 30 new cases in a population of 30,000, which is much lower than the 300 new cases provided. This option underestimates the incidence.

questions.text: True about prevalence:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Increases with increase in duration of disease. Prevalence refers to the proportion of individuals in a population who have a particular disease at a given point in time or over a specific period. Duration of disease plays a significant role in determining prevalence: the longer people live with the disease, the greater the total number of people living with the condition at any given time, which increases the prevalence. If a disease has a longer duration, more individuals will remain affected, thereby raising the prevalence rate. Incorrect Options: A. It is a ratio: This option is partially correct but incomplete. Prevalence is a proportion, not a ratio. It is calculated as the number of existing cases of a disease divided by the total population, and it is expressed as a percentage or a fraction. While it is a comparison of numbers (like a ratio), its specific mathematical definition is a proportion. B. Prevalence rate is the ideal measure for studying disease aetiology or causation: This is incorrect. Prevalence is better suited for understanding the burden of a disease at a particular point in time, but incidence is a more suitable measure for studying disease etiology or causation. Incidence reflects new cases, which are crucial for understanding how a disease develops or spreads. D. Decreases with increase in case fatality: This is incorrect. Case fatality rate (CFR) refers to the proportion of individuals who die from a disease among those who are diagnosed with it. If case fatality increases, people die faster, which would lead to a decrease in the duration of disease, and therefore a potential decrease in prevalence. However, the key factor in prevalence is duration, and increasing case fatality may not immediately result in a significant decrease in prevalence, especially if there are new cases emerging.

questions.text: LJ chart is used for :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Precision. An LJ chart (Lloyd-Jones chart) is used in statistical analysis, particularly in the context of evaluating the precision of a measurement or diagnostic test. Precision refers to the consistency or repeatability of a measurement — how close repeated measurements are to each other. The LJ chart is a graphical tool that helps assess the variability in data, providing a way to evaluate how well a measurement can be reproduced. Incorrect Options: A. Accuracy: Accuracy refers to how close a measured value is to the true or actual value. While precision and accuracy are related concepts, the LJ chart specifically evaluates precision, not accuracy. Accuracy is typically assessed through other methods like comparing measurements to a known standard. C. Odds: Odds refer to the likelihood of a particular event occurring compared to it not occurring. An LJ chart is not designed to assess odds; instead, it is used to evaluate precision, which involves assessing the variability or spread of measurements. D. Likelihood ratio: The likelihood ratio is a statistic used in diagnostic testing, calculated by comparing the likelihood of a given result under two different hypotheses. An LJ chart is not specifically used for likelihood ratios; it focuses on the precision of measurements.

questions.text: If a biochemical test gives the same reading for a sample on repeated testing it is inferred that the measurement is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Precise. When a biochemical test gives the same reading for a sample on repeated testing, it indicates precision. Precision refers to the consistency or reproducibility of a measurement. If the same result is obtained consistently under the same conditions, the measurement is precise, even if it is not necessarily accurate (i.e., close to the true value). Incorrect Options: B. Accurate: Accuracy refers to how close the test result is to the true or actual value. If a test gives the same result repeatedly but that result is far from the true value, it is precise but not accurate. Accuracy cannot be inferred from repeated testing alone; it requires comparison to the true value. C. Specific: Specificity refers to the ability of a test to correctly identify individuals who do not have the condition (true negative rate). It is not related to the consistency of the test results, so it is not inferred from repeated testing of the same sample. D. Sensitive: Sensitivity refers to the ability of a test to correctly identify individuals who have the condition (true positive rate). Like specificity, sensitivity is not directly related to the consistency of the test results and cannot be inferred from repeated testing of the same sample.

questions.text: A test which produce similar result when repeated but values obtained are not close to actual/true value .
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Precise but inaccurate. When a test produces similar results upon repeated testing but those results are not close to the actual or true value, it indicates that the test is precise (because the results are consistent) but inaccurate (because the results are not close to the true value). Precision refers to the consistency or repeatability of the test, while accuracy refers to how close the results are to the true value. In this case, the test is reliable in terms of reproducibility but does not provide correct values. Incorrect Options: B. Precise and accurate: This option is incorrect because the results are consistent (precise) but not close to the true value (inaccurate). For a test to be both precise and accurate, the repeated results must be close to the actual value, which is not the case here. C. Imprecise and accurate: This is incorrect because the test is described as producing similar results (which indicates precision). If the results were inconsistent (imprecise), they would not be similar on repeated testing, so this option does not fit the scenario. D. Imprecise and inaccurate: This option is also incorrect because the test is described as giving consistent (precise) results. Imprecision would imply that the results vary, which is not the case here.

questions.text: Validity of a test is based upon all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Precision. Validity of a test refers to how well the test measures what it is intended to measure, or how accurate the test results are in reflecting the true state of the condition being tested. The key components of test validity include: Sensitivity: The ability of a test to correctly identify those with the disease (true positive rate). Specificity: The ability of a test to correctly identify those without the disease (true negative rate). Accuracy: The overall correctness of the test, reflecting how close the results are to the true value (true positives and true negatives). However, precision refers to the consistency or reproducibility of the test results, not the accuracy of the test in identifying the true state of the condition. A test can be precise (repeated results are consistent) but still not valid if those results are far from the true value. Incorrect Options: A. Sensitivity: Sensitivity is a key aspect of test validity, as it reflects the ability of the test to correctly identify those who actually have the condition. B. Specificity: Specificity is also an important factor in test validity because it indicates the ability of the test to correctly identify those who do not have the condition, minimizing false positives. D. Accuracy: Accuracy is crucial for test validity because it measures how close the test results are to the true or actual value, indicating how well the test works in practice.
