questions.text: A new method of measuring haemoglobin levels has been developed . Ten successive readings of a single sample are as following 9.4, 10.4, 9.6, 9.1, 10.8, 12.1, 10.1 9.8, 9.2, 9.5 but the haemoglobin measured by standard calorimetry was 10.2 therefore the given method has :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) High validity, low reliability. Validity refers to how close the results from a measurement method are to the true value or standard value. In this case, the measured values from the new method are close to the standard calorimetry result of 10.2 (ranging from 9.1 to 12.1, with an average around 9.8). Since the values are generally in the range of the true value (10.2), the method shows high validity. Reliability refers to the consistency or repeatability of the measurements. The 10 successive readings vary widely, ranging from 9.1 to 12.1. This variation indicates that the method is not consistent and lacks high reliability. Reliability would be high if the readings were closely clustered around a mean value. Thus, the new method has high validity (because its measurements are close to the true value) but low reliability (due to the wide variation in the readings). Incorrect Options: A. Low validity, low reliability: This option is incorrect because the readings are generally close to the true value, indicating high validity, not low validity. The method does have low reliability, but the validity is higher than low. B. Low validity, high reliability: This option is incorrect because the readings are not far from the true value, meaning the method has high validity, not low validity. The reliability is low, so this option doesn't fit. D. High validity, high reliability: This option is incorrect because, although the method has high validity, the wide variation in readings indicates that it does not have high reliability.

questions.text: All of the following help reduce bias except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Confounder. Confounders are variables that are associated with both the exposure and the outcome but are not part of the causal pathway. They can introduce bias into a study by distorting the apparent relationship between the exposure and outcome. The presence of a confounder does not help to reduce bias; instead, it can increase bias if not properly controlled for in the study design or analysis. Incorrect Options: A. Blinding: Blinding helps reduce bias by preventing participants, researchers, or both from knowing which treatment or intervention a participant is receiving. This helps to prevent personal expectations or knowledge from influencing the study results, reducing observation bias or performance bias. B. Randomization: Randomization helps reduce bias by randomly assigning participants to different groups, ensuring that the groups are comparable at baseline. This helps to control for both known and unknown confounders, reducing selection bias and confounding bias. D. Matching: Matching involves pairing participants with similar characteristics (e.g., age, gender) across the different study groups. This helps to control for potential confounders by ensuring that groups are comparable in terms of these variables, thus reducing confounding bias.

questions.text: The systematic distortion of retrospective studies that can be eliminated by a prospective design is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Recall bias. Recall bias occurs when participants in a study are asked to remember or recall past events, exposures, or behaviors. In retrospective studies, where participants are asked to recall past information, people with certain outcomes or conditions may remember their exposures differently than those without the outcome. This leads to systematic distortion in the data. A prospective design, on the other hand, collects data moving forward in time, meaning there is no need for participants to rely on memory or recall, thus eliminating recall bias. Incorrect Options: A. Confounding: Confounding happens when an external factor is associated with both the exposure and the outcome, which distorts the apparent relationship between them. While prospective designs can help control for confounding through randomization and other methods, they do not eliminate confounding entirely. Confounding is a bias that can occur in both retrospective and prospective studies. B. Effect modification: Effect modification occurs when the relationship between exposure and outcome differs across levels of another variable. It is not a bias or distortion but a true interaction. It cannot be "eliminated" through study design, but rather it is something to identify and interpret carefully in any type of study. D. Measurement bias: Measurement bias refers to errors in the way data is collected, which can occur in both retrospective and prospective studies. Although a prospective study might reduce certain biases in data collection (e.g., through more standardized protocols), it does not eliminate measurement bias altogether. Measurement bias depends on the methods of data collection, not just the study design.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of bias?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Random error. Random error refers to the inherent variability or fluctuations in measurements that occur due to chance. It is unpredictable and does not consistently favor one outcome over another. Unlike bias, which systematically distorts results in a particular direction, random error does not cause a consistent deviation from the truth. While random error affects the precision of measurements, it does not introduce systematic distortion and thus is not considered a cause of bias. Explanation for Incorrect Options: A. Confounding: Confounding occurs when a third variable is associated with both the exposure and the outcome, leading to a distorted or biased estimate of the true relationship between the exposure and outcome. Confounders can cause bias if not properly controlled for. B. Selection: Selection bias happens when the process of selecting participants or data influences the results in a systematic way. For example, if certain groups are more likely to be included in a study than others, it can lead to biased conclusions about the population as a whole. C. Misclassification: Misclassification bias occurs when there are errors in categorizing study participants or exposures. For instance, if people with a certain disease are incorrectly classified as healthy, this leads to bias in the study's findings. Misclassification can occur in both retrospective and prospective studies and can introduce either differential or non-differential bias.

choices.text: It is found equally between the study and the controls groups
It is itself a risk factor for the disease
Confounding can be eliminated by selecting a small group
It is associated either with the exposure or the disease

questions.text: True about confounding factor
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) It is itself a risk factor for the disease. A confounding factor is a variable that is associated with both the exposure and the outcome (disease). It is a risk factor for the disease, which means it can affect the outcome independently of the exposure. If not controlled for, confounding can distort the apparent relationship between the exposure and the disease, making it seem stronger or weaker than it actually is. Incorrect Options: A. It is found equally between the study and the control groups: This is not true because a confounding factor typically differs between the study and control groups. If it were equally distributed, it wouldn't create distortion in the results. Confounding occurs when a factor is more common in one group than the other, leading to biased results. C. Confounding can be eliminated by selecting a small group: This is incorrect because confounding is not resolved simply by changing the sample size. Even with a small group, if the confounder is not controlled for, it can still cause bias. Confounding is addressed through methods like randomization, matching, or statistical adjustment, not just by choosing a small group. D. It is associated either with the exposure or the disease: This is not accurate because a confounder must be associated with both the exposure and the disease. If it is associated with only one of them, it does not create the bias needed to be considered a confounder.

questions.text: A study revealed that in a study group, intake of beta carotene decreases carcinoma of colon but it actually may be due to increased intake of dietary fibre. This is due to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Confounding factor occurs when an external variable (a confounder) is associated with both the exposure (in this case, beta carotene intake) and the outcome (carcinoma of the colon), but is not part of the causal pathway. In the scenario described, the observed effect (reduced carcinoma of the colon) may actually be due to a third variable (increased intake of dietary fiber), which is related to both beta carotene intake and the reduction in cancer risk. This makes dietary fiber a confounder. The confounding factor distorts the apparent relationship between the exposure (beta carotene) and the outcome (colon carcinoma). Explanation for Incorrect Options: B. Misclassification bias: Misclassification bias occurs when participants are incorrectly classified in terms of their exposure or outcome status. For example, misclassifying someone as having beta carotene intake when they did not, or vice versa. However, this situation involves an external confounder, not a misclassification of participants. C. Selection bias: Selection bias refers to a bias that occurs when the participants included in the study are not representative of the general population, or when the selection of participants is systematically different between groups. This is not the issue described here; the bias is due to an external confounding factor rather than selection-related issues. D. Sampling error: Sampling error occurs when the sample size is too small or not randomly selected, leading to random deviations from the true population parameters. This does not explain the distortion caused by an external factor (dietary fiber) affecting the relationship between beta carotene and cancer risk

questions.text: Confounding can be removed by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) All of the above. Confounding can be controlled or minimized by several methods, including: A. Assign confounders equally to both cases and controls: Ensuring that the confounding variables are equally distributed between the case and control groups helps to eliminate the potential bias introduced by these confounders. This can be achieved through study design and careful selection of cases and controls. B. Randomization: Randomization in experimental studies (such as clinical trials) helps to randomly assign participants to treatment groups. This process ensures that confounders (both known and unknown) are equally distributed across the treatment groups, thus minimizing their impact on the outcome and reducing confounding bias. C. Matching: Matching is a technique often used in observational studies, where participants are paired based on key confounding variables (e.g., age, sex, socioeconomic status) to ensure that the groups being compared are similar in terms of these confounders. This helps control for confounding by balancing the groups on the confounding factors.

questions.text: A study has been done to establish relationship between smoking and lung cancer, it was found that association was more in people who exercise less and less in people who exercise more. In this situation exercise is a
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Effect modifier. Effect modifier (also known as an interaction effect) occurs when the relationship between the exposure (smoking) and the outcome (lung cancer) is different at different levels of another variable (in this case, exercise). This means that the effect of smoking on lung cancer varies depending on whether the person exercises more or less. The fact that the association is stronger in people who exercise less and weaker in those who exercise more suggests that exercise modifies the effect of smoking on lung cancer risk. Incorrect Options: A. Bias: Bias refers to systematic errors or distortions in a study that lead to incorrect conclusions. While effect modification could lead to unexpected patterns, it is not considered a bias, as it reflects a true interaction between variables, not a flaw in the study design or methodology. C. Confounding factor: Confounding occurs when a third variable is associated with both the exposure (smoking) and the outcome (lung cancer) but is not part of the causal pathway. If exercise were a confounder, it would distort the relationship between smoking and lung cancer in a way that could be controlled for. However, in this case, the relationship between smoking and lung cancer changes depending on exercise levels, which points to effect modification, not confounding. D. Collinear factor: Collinearity refers to a situation where two or more independent variables in a study are highly correlated with each other, making it difficult to distinguish their individual effects. Exercise and smoking are not necessarily collinear, and the relationship described here indicates an interaction effect, not collinearity.

questions.text: Researcher wants to study the blood level of lipids among people who smoke and those who do not but he is now concerned that the smokers might differ from non smokers in there diet exercise etc as well. This concern is known as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Selection bias. Selection bias occurs when there are systematic differences between the groups being compared. In this case, the researcher is concerned that smokers and non-smokers might differ in factors such as diet, exercise, etc., which could affect the study's results. These differences could create a biased comparison between the two groups, as the outcome (blood levels of lipids) might be influenced by factors other than smoking, leading to inaccurate conclusions. Therefore, this concern reflects selection bias. Incorrect Options: A. Recall bias: Recall bias occurs when participants have difficulty remembering past events or exposures, leading to systematic errors in the data. This does not apply to the current concern, as the researcher is not dealing with memory-related issues but with differences between groups (smokers vs. non-smokers) in other factors like diet and exercise. B. Information bias: Information bias refers to errors in how data is collected or measured. It can occur if there are inconsistencies or inaccuracies in data recording, but in this case, the concern is about the inherent differences between the two groups (smokers vs. non-smokers), not errors in data collection or measurement. C. Hawthorne bias: Hawthorne bias occurs when participants alter their behavior because they are aware they are being observed or studied. This does not apply to the current situation, as the concern is about the inherent differences between groups rather than the participants' awareness of being studied.

questions.text: Berkesonian bias is a type of :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Berksonian bias (also known as Berkson's bias) is a type of selection bias that occurs in case-control studies when the cases and controls are selected from hospital or clinic populations. This bias happens because both the exposure and the outcome are related to the likelihood of being admitted to the hospital, meaning that individuals with certain characteristics (such as more severe disease or multiple risk factors) are more likely to be included. As a result, the sample may not be representative of the general population, and the observed association between the exposure and outcome may be distorted. Incorrect Options: B. Interviewer bias: Interviewer bias occurs when the interviewer influences the responses of participants or records data in a biased manner, often unconsciously. While this could affect the data collection process, Berksonian bias is not related to how interviewers interact with participants but rather to how cases and controls are selected in a study. C. Information bias: Information bias refers to inaccuracies in the collection of data, such as errors in measurement or reporting. This includes misclassification of participants based on exposure or outcome status. Berksonian bias, however, is related to the selection of participants, not errors in information collection. D. Recall bias: Recall bias occurs when participants do not accurately remember or report past exposures, leading to systematic errors in the data. Berksonian bias is not about memory or reporting issues but is a result of how participants are selected into a study.

Questioning the cases more thoroughly ac compared to controls

questions.text: Berkesonian bias is due to :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Berksonian bias occurs when there is a selection bias in case-control studies that results from the way cases and controls are chosen, particularly when the sample is taken from a hospital or clinic. In such settings, the likelihood of being admitted to the hospital can be influenced by both the presence of the disease and the exposure. For instance, individuals with more severe forms of a disease (or multiple risk factors) are more likely to be hospitalized, leading to a skewed sample. This can distort the relationship between the exposure and the disease because the population being studied is not representative of the general population but rather of those with a higher risk of hospitalization. Incorrect Options: A. Presence of confounding factors in both cases and controls: While confounding factors can influence the results of a study, Berksonian bias specifically refers to a bias caused by the way cases and controls are selected, not by confounders. Confounding factors may be a problem in studies but are not the cause of Berksonian bias. B. Questioning the cases more thoroughly as compared to controls: This would be an example of interviewer bias rather than Berksonian bias. Berksonian bias is related to the selection of participants, not differences in how the participants are questioned during the study. D. Better recall by the cases as compared to controls: Recall bias is the distortion that arises when participants' ability to remember past exposures differs between cases and controls. While this can affect case-control studies, it is not the cause of Berksonian bias, which is about selection rather than recall.

questions.text: The analytical study where population is the unit of study is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ecological. In an ecological study, the unit of analysis is typically a population or group (such as a city, country, or community), rather than individuals. These studies examine the relationship between exposure and outcome variables at the group level, rather than the individual level. For example, an ecological study might investigate the correlation between average air pollution levels in different cities and the rates of lung cancer in those cities. Ecological studies are often used to explore large-scale patterns and trends in health data. Incorrect Options: A. Cross-sectional: In a cross-sectional study, the unit of analysis is usually the individual, not a population or group. Cross-sectional studies are used to assess the prevalence of a disease or exposure in a population at a specific point in time. C. Case-control: In a case-control study, the unit of analysis is also the individual, where cases (individuals with the disease) are compared to controls (individuals without the disease) to identify potential risk factors or exposures. The study focuses on individuals, not populations. D. Cohort: In a cohort study, the unit of analysis is again the individual, as participants are followed over time to assess the relationship between exposures and outcomes. The study compares the incidence of outcomes in exposed versus unexposed individuals.

questions.text: Studying distribution of disease or characteristics in human population & identifying the characteristics with which disease seem to associated is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Descriptive epidemiology. Descriptive epidemiology is concerned with the distribution of disease and health-related characteristics in populations. It involves studying how disease varies across different groups based on variables like time, place, and person. Descriptive studies aim to identify patterns or trends in the frequency and distribution of diseases, such as who is affected (person), where it occurs (place), and when it occurs (time). This type of epidemiology is foundational for generating hypotheses that can later be tested in analytical studies. Incorrect Options: B. Experimental epidemiology: Experimental epidemiology involves interventions or experiments, such as randomized controlled trials (RCTs), to test hypotheses about disease prevention or treatment. This is focused on cause-and-effect relationships rather than simply observing the distribution of disease. C. Analytical epidemiology: Analytical epidemiology is focused on understanding the causes or risk factors of diseases. It involves studying the relationship between exposures (such as smoking, diet, etc.) and outcomes (such as disease incidence). This typically involves case-control or cohort studies rather than just describing the distribution of disease. D. Ecological epidemiology: Ecological epidemiology involves studying the health outcomes of populations at a group level (e.g., regions, countries) rather than individuals. It focuses on environmental or societal factors and how they relate to disease patterns in populations.

questions.text: The ratio between the incidence of disease among exposed and nonexposed is called:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Relative risk. Relative risk (RR), also known as the risk ratio, is the ratio of the incidence of a disease in an exposed group to the incidence of the same disease in a non-exposed group. It is used in cohort studies to measure the strength of the association between exposure and disease. A relative risk greater than 1 suggests that the exposure is associated with an increased risk of disease, while a relative risk less than 1 suggests a protective effect of the exposure. Incorrect Options: A. Causal risk: Causal risk is not a standard term used in epidemiology. The term you're likely thinking of is causal risk factor, which refers to an exposure that directly contributes to the development of a disease. It does not refer to a ratio between exposed and non-exposed groups. C. Attributable risk: Attributable risk is the difference in the incidence of disease between the exposed and non-exposed groups. It measures how much of the disease risk in the exposed group can be attributed to the exposure. It is not a ratio, but rather a difference in risk. D. Odds ratio: The odds ratio (OR) is a measure of association used in case-control studies. It compares the odds of exposure among cases (those with the disease) to the odds of exposure among controls (those without the disease). While similar in purpose to relative risk, it is not the same and is used in different types of studies.

questions.text: Hawthorne effect is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The Hawthorne effect refers to the phenomenon where participants alter their behavior because they are aware that they are being observed or studied. This effect can occur in any type of study where participants know they are part of the research, but it is particularly noted in cohort studies, where individuals are often followed over time. In cohort studies, the subjects may change their behaviors, such as improving their health habits, simply because they are aware of being monitored, which could influence the results of the study. Incorrect Options: A. Case-control study: The Hawthorne effect is less likely to be a significant issue in case-control studies because these studies usually involve retrospective data collection, and participants are not being followed over a period of time. In case-control studies, the exposure history is often assessed through interviews or existing records, reducing the chances of participants modifying their behavior due to awareness of being observed. C. Cross-sectional study: While the Hawthorne effect could occur in cross-sectional studies, the nature of these studies — which assess exposure and outcome at a single point in time — typically doesn't lead to long-term behavioral changes. The Hawthorne effect is more prominent in studies that involve ongoing observation over time. D. Retrospective cohort study: Retrospective cohort studies typically look back at historical data, and because they often rely on pre-existing records or recollections of past exposures, the Hawthorne effect is less relevant. Participants in these studies usually aren't being observed in real-time, reducing the likelihood of them changing their behavior because of the study.

questions.text: A study compared 150 children with a particular disease with 300 disease free children to examine past experiences that may contribute to the development of the illness. What kind of study is this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Case-control. This study is a case-control study, which is used to investigate the association between exposures and outcomes (in this case, past experiences and the development of a particular disease). In a case-control study, individuals with the disease (cases) are compared to individuals without the disease (controls). The aim is to look back retrospectively to identify factors (such as past experiences) that may be associated with the disease. The study described involves 150 children with the disease (cases) and 300 disease-free children (controls), which fits the typical design of a case-control study. Incorrect Options: A. Cohort: A cohort study involves following a group of individuals over time, typically to observe the development of disease based on exposure status. In this study, there is no mention of following children over time, so it is not a cohort study. Cohort studies often begin by selecting people based on exposure, then track the incidence of disease. B. Controlled clinical trial: A controlled clinical trial involves randomly assigning participants to different interventions (such as treatment or placebo groups) to evaluate the effect of those interventions. The study described does not mention any intervention or random assignment, so it is not a controlled clinical trial. C. Case series: A case series is a descriptive study that reports on a group of people with a particular disease, but it does not have a control group. The study described involves a comparison between diseased children and healthy controls, making it different from a case series.

questions.text: Best study of first choice for assessment of UNKNOWN or New disease with no etiological hypothesis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Descriptive epidemiology. Explanation for Correct Answer (D): Descriptive epidemiology is the best study design for the assessment of unknown or new diseases when there is no specific etiological hypothesis. This type of study aims to describe the distribution and patterns of disease in terms of time, place, and person. It involves observing and recording the frequency and characteristics of a disease in a population, which can help generate hypotheses about potential causes or risk factors, especially for newly emerging diseases. Descriptive epidemiology is key to recognizing disease outbreaks or identifying trends that might suggest further investigation. Incorrect Options: A. Cohort study: A cohort study is typically used to investigate the relationship between exposure and the development of disease over time, but it requires some level of understanding of the exposure or risk factor. It is not the first choice for studying a new or unknown disease without any prior hypothesis, as it is more focused on examining causal relationships between exposures and outcomes. B. Case-control study: A case-control study compares individuals with a disease (cases) to those without it (controls) to explore potential risk factors. While case-control studies are useful for identifying risk factors for known diseases, they are less effective when studying a new or unknown disease without a hypothesis, as they depend on having defined cases and controls. C. Cross-sectional study: A cross-sectional study looks at a population at a single point in time, assessing the prevalence of a disease or condition and its association with certain characteristics or exposures. While useful for understanding disease prevalence, it may not be the most effective design for studying a new disease without an etiological hypothesis because it doesn't allow for the generation of new insights about the natural history or causality of the disease.

questions.text: 20 pregnant women were asked about the history of smoking when they came for regular antenatal visit and then followed up to see how many of them had low birth weight babies. What is the type of study?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) This is a prospective cohort study because it follows a group of individuals (the pregnant women) over time to observe an outcome (low birth weight babies) based on their exposure (history of smoking). In a prospective cohort study, participants are identified based on their exposure status (in this case, smoking history) and are followed over a period of time to see if they develop the outcome (low birth weight). This type of study is used to determine the temporal relationship between exposure and outcome. Incorrect Options: A. Case-control: A case-control study would involve comparing individuals with a specific outcome (low birth weight babies, in this case) to those without the outcome, looking backward to identify potential exposures or risk factors. This study design is retrospective, unlike the prospective design described in the question. C. Cross-sectional: A cross-sectional study looks at the relationship between exposure and outcome at a single point in time, rather than over a period of time. This study design does not follow participants over time, so it is not appropriate for this scenario where the women are being followed to see the outcomes later. D. Ecological: Ecological studies examine group-level data rather than individual-level data. This study design looks at associations between exposures and outcomes at the population or community level, rather than on an individual basis. Since this study follows individuals and looks at their individual outcomes, it is not an ecological study.

questions.text: A cohort study on 7000 subjects who were smokers over a ten- year period was done & 70 subjects developed lung cancer, concurrent evaluation of general population in catchment area of hospital, out of 7000 nonsmoker subjects only 7 developed lung cancer. The RR for developing lung cancer is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) To calculate the Relative Risk (RR), we use the formula: RR= Incidence in Exposed Group / Incidence in Non-Exposed Group Where: Incidence in the Exposed Group (Smokers) = Number of smokers who developed lung cancer / Total number of smokers = 70 / 7000 = 0.01 (1% incidence) Incidence in the Non-Exposed Group (Non-Smokers) = Number of non-smokers who developed lung cancer / Total number of non-smokers = 7 / 7000 = 0.001 (0.1% incidence) Now, calculating the RR: RR= 0.01 / 0.001 = 10 Incorrect Options: A. 1: A Relative Risk of 1 would indicate that the exposure (smoking) does not increase the risk of the disease (lung cancer), meaning the incidence in the exposed group is the same as the incidence in the non-exposed group. Since smoking increases the risk, this is not correct. C. 100: A Relative Risk of 100 would mean that smokers are 100 times more likely to develop lung cancer than non-smokers. While smoking does increase the risk, the relative risk is much smaller (10), so this is an overestimation. D. 0.1 A Relative Risk of 0.1 would suggest that smokers are less likely to develop lung cancer compared to non-smokers, which is the opposite of the expected result, given that smoking is a known risk factor for lung cancer.

questions.text: In an investigation to study the effect of smoking on renal cell cancer, it is observed that 30 of the 50 patients were smokers as compared to 10 out of 50 control subjects. The odd ratio of renal cancer associated with smoking will be:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) To calculate the Odds Ratio (OR), we use the following formula: OR= (a/c)/(b/d) a = Number of smokers with renal cancer = 30 b = Number of non-smokers with renal cancer = 50 - 30 = 20 c = Number of smokers without renal cancer (controls) = 10 d = Number of non-smokers without renal cancer (controls) = 50 - 10 = 40 Now, substitute these values into the formula: OR=(30/20)/(10/40) = 1.5/0.25 = 6.0 This means that the odds of having renal cell cancer are 6 times higher among smokers than non-smokers. Incorrect Options: A. 3.0: This would suggest that the odds of renal cell cancer among smokers are 3 times higher than among non-smokers, which does not match the calculation based on the given data. The correct OR is 6.0, not 3.0. B. 0.33: An OR of 0.33 would suggest that smokers have a lower risk of developing renal cell cancer compared to non-smokers, which is not consistent with the data provided. The odds ratio calculated indicates an increased risk for smokers. D. 0.16: An OR of 0.16 would imply a very small likelihood of renal cell cancer among smokers, much lower than for non-smokers. This does not reflect the observed data and is not the correct OR.

questions.text: Matching is done for removal of :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Known confounding. Matching is a method used in observational studies (such as case-control studies) to control for confounding by ensuring that the study groups (e.g., cases and controls) are comparable in terms of certain characteristics, such as age, sex, or other known factors that might influence the outcome. By matching the cases and controls on these factors, the researcher aims to remove the effect of known confounding variables, making the comparison between the groups more valid and reducing the risk of bias caused by these variables. Incorrect Options: A. Bias: While matching can help control for confounding, it does not necessarily eliminate all types of bias. Bias refers to systematic errors that can distort the results, and matching specifically targets confounding (the distortion caused by extraneous variables), not general bias. C. Unknown confounding: Matching can only control for known confounding factors—those that are identified prior to or during the design of the study. Unknown confounding factors (those not considered or measured in the study) cannot be controlled for through matching. D. Known confounding + Unknown confounding: Since matching specifically addresses known confounding factors, it does not simultaneously control for both known and unknown confounders. Unknown confounders would require different strategies, such as statistical adjustment or further research to identify them.

Incorrect Options:: B. 30: A Relative Risk of 30 would imply that smokers are 30 times more likely to develop hypertension compared to non-smokers, which is much higher than the calculated RR of 3. This is an overestimation. C. 1/3: A Relative Risk of 1/3 would suggest that smokers are less likely to develop hypertension compared to non-smokers, which contradicts the observed data where smokers have a higher incidence of hypertension. D. 6: A Relative Risk of 6 would suggest that smokers are 6 times more likely to develop hypertension compared to non-smokers, which is higher than the calculated RR of 3. This is an overestimation.

questions.text: The physical examination records of the entire incoming freshman class of 1935 at the University of Minnesota were examined in 1977 to see if their recorded height and weight at the time of admission to university was related to their chance of developing CHD. This is an example of.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Retrospective cohort. This study involves looking backwards in time at records from the incoming freshman class of 1935 to examine if their height and weight at the time of admission were related to their future development of coronary heart disease (CHD). This type of study is known as a retrospective cohort study, where researchers use existing data (from the past) to study the outcomes (in this case, CHD) in a cohort that was defined in the past. In retrospective cohort studies, the researcher does not influence the exposure or outcome, but instead studies the exposure (height and weight) that occurred in the past and links it to a future outcome (CHD). The cohort (freshman class of 1935) is followed forward in time, but the data are collected from past records. Explanation for Incorrect Options: A. Cross sectional study: A cross-sectional study examines data at one point in time, providing a snapshot of the relationship between exposure and outcome. In this case, the study is examining data from the past and linking it to future outcomes, so it cannot be a cross-sectional study. B. Concurrent cohort: A concurrent cohort study involves following a cohort from the present time and studying their outcomes as they occur. The study in question uses past records (from 1935), so it is not concurrent. D. Clinical trial: A clinical trial is a prospective study where participants are assigned to different groups to receive interventions, and the outcomes are measured. This study does not involve any intervention or treatment assignment, so it is not a clinical trial.

questions.text: Retrospective cohort studies are characterized by all the following except ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Required sample size is smaller than that needed for a concurrent cohort study. Retrospective cohort studies do not necessarily require smaller sample sizes compared to concurrent cohort studies. In fact, the sample size in a retrospective cohort study can be similar to or sometimes even larger, depending on the availability of historical data and the outcome's rarity. In retrospective cohort studies, researchers rely on existing data, but that doesn't automatically mean the required sample size is smaller. The primary advantage is that the study is quicker and less expensive because it uses data that have already been collected. Incorrect Options: A. The study groups are exposed and non-exposed: This is true for retrospective cohort studies. In a retrospective cohort study, participants are categorized based on their past exposure (such as smoking or a specific medical condition), and the outcomes (such as disease development) are studied in both the exposed and non-exposed groups. B. Incidence rates are compared: This is correct. Retrospective cohort studies compare the incidence rates of the outcome (e.g., disease development) in the exposed group versus the non-exposed group. This is similar to a concurrent cohort study, where incidence rates are also compared, but the data collection happens in real-time. D. The required sample size is similar to that needed for a concurrent cohort study: This is also true in many cases. Even though retrospective cohort studies use pre-existing data, they can still require a sample size similar to that of a concurrent cohort study, depending on the study's objectives, the rarity of the disease, and the availability of reliable historical data

questions.text: Migration study is used for
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Environmental and genetic factor in a disease in a population. A migration study is used to investigate how migration patterns might influence the prevalence of diseases in different populations. By examining populations that have migrated, researchers can assess how environmental and genetic factors influence the occurrence of diseases. For example, if a population moves from a region with a low rate of a certain disease to a region with a high rate of that disease, a migration study can help identify how environmental exposures or genetic susceptibility play a role in the disease's prevalence. Incorrect Options: A. Socio-demographic reasons for migration of a population: Migration studies can indeed look into the socio-demographic reasons for migration (such as job opportunities, education, or political instability). However, in the context of health and disease, migration studies are more often focused on understanding how migration impacts disease occurrence, rather than just the socio-demographic factors. B. Prevalence of a disease in a population: While migration studies might help assess the prevalence of disease in different populations, the primary focus is usually on understanding the role of environmental and genetic factors rather than simply measuring disease prevalence. Prevalence studies typically assess how widespread a disease is in a specific population, without necessarily considering migration or its impact. D. Disease with a long incubation period: Migration studies are not specifically used to study diseases with long incubation periods. While migration can be studied in relation to diseases that take time to develop, it is not uniquely associated with diseases that have a long incubation period.

questions.text: All the following are advantages of case control studies except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Relative risk can be calculated. In a case-control study, participants are selected based on the presence or absence of the disease (cases and controls), and then the exposure history is assessed. Relative risk (RR) cannot be directly calculated in case-control studies because these studies are not based on measuring the incidence of disease in a population. Instead, they are based on comparing the odds of exposure between the cases and controls. Therefore, relative risk is typically calculated in cohort studies (prospective studies) where both the exposed and unexposed groups are followed over time to determine their incidence of disease. Incorrect Options: A. Useful in rare diseases: Case-control studies are particularly useful for studying rare diseases because they focus on individuals who already have the disease (cases). This allows researchers to gather enough data on rare diseases without needing a large sample size, which would be difficult to achieve in cohort studies. C. Odds ratio can be calculated: In a case-control study, odds ratios (OR) are commonly calculated. The odds ratio compares the odds of exposure among cases to the odds of exposure among controls. This is a key measure of association in case-control studies. D. Cost-effective and inexpensive: Case-control studies are generally more cost-effective and inexpensive than cohort studies because they are retrospective. Researchers use existing records or data, so they don’t need to follow up participants over long periods, making the study design cheaper and quicker.

questions.text: A one-day census of inpatients in a mental hospital could:

questions.text: Incidence of carcinoma cervix in women with multiple sexual partners is 5 times incidence seen in those with a single partner. Based on this, what is the attributable risk?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 80%. Attributable risk (AR) is a measure that quantifies the proportion of the incidence of a disease in the exposed population that can be attributed to the exposure. It is calculated using the formula: Attributable Risk (AR)= Incidence in Exposed-Incidence in Unexposed/Incidence in Exposed In this case, the incidence of carcinoma cervix in women with multiple sexual partners is 5 times higher than in women with a single sexual partner. If we assume that the incidence in women with a single partner is the baseline (let’s call it 1 unit), then the incidence in women with multiple partners would be 5 units. The attributable risk can be calculated as: AR=-5-1/5 = 1-4 = 0.80 So, the attributable risk is 80%. This means that 80% of the incidence of carcinoma cervix in women with multiple sexual partners can be attributed to the exposure (having multiple partners). Incorrect Options: A. 20%: This would be incorrect, as the correct attributable risk is 80%, not 20%. B. 40%: This is also incorrect. The calculation leads to 80%, not 40%. C. 50%: Again, this is incorrect. The attributable risk here is 80%, not 50%.

questions.text: Several studies have shown that 85% of cases of lung cancer are due to smoking. It is a measure of :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Attributable risk. In this case, the statement that 85% of lung cancer cases are due to smoking is an example of attributable risk, which quantifies the proportion of disease cases in the exposed population (smokers) that can be attributed to the exposure (smoking). Attributable risk is a measure used to understand how much of the risk of a disease in an exposed group (in this case, smokers) is due to the exposure itself (smoking). It helps in estimating the portion of disease cases in the exposed group that would not occur if they were not exposed. Incorrect Options: A. Incidence rate: Incidence rate refers to the number of new cases of a disease occurring in a specific population over a certain period of time. The statement does not provide information about the number of new cases but rather the proportion of cases that are attributed to smoking, so it is not an incidence rate. B. Relative risk: Relative risk compares the risk of disease between an exposed group (smokers) and a non-exposed group (non-smokers). It does not tell us what portion of the disease cases in the exposed group are attributable to the exposure, so it's not a relative risk. D. Population attributable risk: Population attributable risk refers to the proportion of all cases of a disease in the entire population (not just the exposed group) that can be attributed to a specific exposure. The statement provided is about the proportion in the exposed group, making it attributable risk, not population attributable risk.

questions.text: Framingham Heart Study is an example of :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cohort study. The Framingham Heart Study is a well-known cohort study that began in 1948. In a cohort study, a group of individuals (cohort) is followed over time to observe the development of specific outcomes, such as heart disease in this case. The study initially followed a group of individuals from Framingham, Massachusetts, and collected data on various risk factors for heart disease, including smoking, cholesterol levels, and blood pressure. Over time, the study has expanded to include multiple generations, providing valuable insights into cardiovascular health. Incorrect responses: A. Case Control study: A case-control study looks retrospectively at individuals who have a specific disease (cases) and compares them to those who do not have the disease (controls). The Framingham Heart Study is not a case-control study because it involves prospective data collection and follows participants over time, rather than comparing those with and without disease at a single point in time. C. Cross-Sectional Study: A cross-sectional study examines data from a population at a single point in time to assess the prevalence of a condition. The Framingham Heart Study is not cross-sectional because it follows participants over a long period, rather than taking a snapshot of the population at one moment. D. Interventional study: An interventional study involves the active manipulation of variables or interventions (e.g., giving a treatment or changing behavior) to observe the effects. The Framingham Heart Study is observational, meaning no interventions are made—researchers simply observe the participants over time.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not correct?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) A cohort study is more appropriate when the disease or exposure under investigation is rare, in comparison to case control study. This statement is incorrect. Case control studies are more appropriate when the disease or exposure under investigation is rare. In a cohort study, you would need to follow a large number of individuals over time to detect enough cases of the rare disease, which makes cohort studies less efficient and more expensive for rare diseases. On the other hand, a case-control study starts with people who already have the disease (cases) and compares them to those who do not (controls), so it is more efficient for studying rare diseases. Correct statements: A. A cohort study is more expensive in comparison to case control study: This is correct. Cohort studies often require long-term follow-up and involve monitoring large groups of people over time, which makes them more expensive than case-control studies, which are generally quicker and less costly. B. A cohort study starts with people exposed to risk factor or suspected cause while case control study starts with disease: This is correct. In a cohort study, participants are grouped based on exposure to a risk factor or suspected cause and then followed to see if they develop the disease. In a case-control study, participants are grouped based on whether they have the disease (cases) or not (controls), and then their previous exposures are compared. C. A long follow-up period often needed with delayed results in a cohort study whereas a case control study yields relatively quick results: This is correct. Because cohort studies follow participants over a long period to observe outcomes, they often take a long time to yield results. Case-control studies, on the other hand, examine existing data and provide quicker results.

questions.text: For a community physician which of the following is more important?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Attributable risk. Attributable risk is a measure that estimates the proportion of a disease or health outcome in a population that can be attributed to a specific risk factor. For a community physician, understanding attributable risk is crucial because it helps to quantify how much of the disease burden in the population is caused by a particular exposure or risk factor. This information can guide public health decisions and resource allocation, enabling the physician to prioritize interventions that target modifiable risk factors and reduce the overall burden of disease in the community. Incorrect responses: A. Relative risk: While relative risk is important in epidemiological studies to understand the strength of the association between exposure and outcome, it is typically more relevant in cohort studies or clinical settings. For community-level decisions, attributable risk is often more applicable. B. Odds ratio: The odds ratio is commonly used in case-control studies to estimate the odds of exposure in cases versus controls. However, for community physicians, odds ratios might not be as directly useful for guiding public health interventions compared to attributable risk, which directly reflects the impact of a risk factor on disease burden in the population. D. Prevalence of the disease: Prevalence is an important measure to understand how common a disease is in a population. However, for a community physician focused on prevention and risk reduction, attributable risk is a more actionable metric as it shows the impact of specific exposures on disease rates.

questions.text: Which of following research methods studies have only people who are initially free of disease of interest?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cohort study. A cohort study involves following a group of people who are initially free of the disease of interest to see who develops the disease over time. This type of study is particularly useful for investigating the causes or risk factors for a disease, as it tracks exposures and outcomes prospectively. Because the participants start out free of the disease, the study can assess how different exposures might influence the development of the disease. Incorrect responses: A. Case control study: In a case-control study, individuals are selected based on whether they have the disease (cases) or do not have the disease (controls). Therefore, the people in the study may already have the disease at the start, so they are not necessarily free of the disease when the study begins. B. Case series study: A case series study typically follows a group of patients with a specific disease or condition. It does not include people who are initially free of the disease. Rather, it focuses on individuals who already have the disease to describe the characteristics of those cases. C. Prevalence survey: A prevalence survey measures the proportion of individuals in a population who have a disease at a specific point in time. It does not involve following people over time or focusing solely on those free of the disease at the outset. Instead, it looks at the existing cases in the population at the moment of the survey.

questions.text: False about Odds Ratio is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) It is always >1. The odds ratio (OR) is a measure of association between exposure and an outcome, and it can take any positive value. It can be less than 1, equal to 1, or greater than 1, depending on the nature of the relationship between the exposure and the outcome. If the OR is greater than 1, it indicates a positive association (exposure increases the odds of the outcome). If the OR is less than 1, it indicates a negative association (exposure decreases the odds of the outcome, i.e., a protective effect). If the OR is equal to 1, there is no association between exposure and outcome. Therefore, it is incorrect to say that the odds ratio is always greater than 1. Incorrect responses: A. It is always positive: This statement is correct. The odds ratio is always a positive value because it represents the ratio of two odds, and odds cannot be negative. An OR can range from 0 to infinity, but it will always be positive. B. It can be 0.3: This statement is correct. An odds ratio can be 0.3, which would indicate that the odds of the outcome are lower in the exposed group compared to the unexposed group. This would suggest a protective effect of the exposure. C. It can be 3.0: This statement is correct. An odds ratio of 3.0 indicates that the odds of the outcome are three times higher in the exposed group compared to the unexposed group, showing a positive association between the exposure and the outcome.

questions.text: An Odds ratio=1 indicates that the association between the two factors is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Does not exist. An odds ratio of 1 indicates no association between the two factors being studied. In other words, the odds of the outcome occurring are the same for both the exposed and unexposed groups. This means that the exposure does not influence the likelihood of the outcome, and thus, there is no relationship or association between the exposure and the outcome. Incorrect responses: A. Is Perfect: This is incorrect. A perfect association would mean that the exposure is completely predictive of the outcome, either always causing it or completely preventing it. An OR of 1 indicates no such perfect association. B. Is low: This is incorrect. An odds ratio of 1 does not reflect a low association; it reflects the absence of an association altogether. C. Is high: This is incorrect. A high association would correspond to an OR greater than 1 (indicating a positive relationship) or less than 1 (indicating a protective effect). An OR of 1 means there is no significant association, not a high one.

questions.text: Which of the following bias can be reduced by allowing equal interview time?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Interviewer bias. Interviewer bias refers to the systematic differences in the way data are collected or interpreted based on the characteristics or behavior of the interviewer. By ensuring that all participants are given equal interview time, it helps reduce any unintentional influence the interviewer might have on the responses. This approach minimizes the opportunity for the interviewer to lead or bias participants in any particular direction during data collection. Incorrect responses: A. Berkson's bias: Berkson's bias occurs when there is a selection bias due to the study population being chosen from a hospital or clinical setting, which is not representative of the general population. This bias cannot be reduced by equalizing interview time because it arises from how participants are selected, not from the interview process itself. B. Recall bias: Recall bias happens when participants have difficulty accurately remembering past events or exposures, which is particularly common in retrospective studies. Equalizing interview time does not address this issue, as recall bias is related to the participant's memory, not the interview process. C. Selection bias: Selection bias arises when the sample population is not representative of the general population, typically due to how participants are selected for the study. Equalizing interview time will not reduce selection bias because this bias is related to the inclusion and exclusion criteria of the study, not the interview process.

questions.text: Which of the following is ideal to ensure similarity between experimental & control groups?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Stratified randomization. Stratified randomization is an ideal method to ensure similarity between experimental and control groups by dividing participants into subgroups (strata) based on key characteristics (e.g., age, gender, disease severity) and then randomly assigning participants from each subgroup to the experimental or control groups. This helps ensure that the groups are balanced in terms of these important variables, reducing the chance of confounding factors influencing the study results. Incorrect responses: A. Randomization: While randomization is an effective method for ensuring that participants are randomly assigned to either the experimental or control group, it does not guarantee that key characteristics are evenly distributed between the two groups. Randomization alone may lead to imbalances in important variables, especially in smaller sample sizes. B. Matching: Matching involves selecting individuals in the experimental group and the control group who are similar in terms of certain characteristics (e.g., age, gender). While this can help control for confounders, it is not as effective as stratified randomization in larger studies where randomization can be done more effectively across many strata to ensure balance. D. Restriction: Restriction involves limiting the study to participants who meet certain criteria (e.g., excluding those with certain comorbidities). While this reduces heterogeneity in the study sample, it does not ensure similarity between experimental and control groups, especially in terms of factors not accounted for by the restrictions.

questions.text: Incidence rate of lung cancer among smokers is 10 per 1000 and among Non- smokers is 1 per 1000. The extent to which lung cancer can be attributed to smoking is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 90%. To calculate the attributable risk (AR) or the proportion of lung cancer cases that can be attributed to smoking, we use the following formula: Attributable risk (AR)= Incidence rate in exposed group / Incidence rate in unexposed group/Incidence rate in exposed group Given the following data: • Incidence rate in smokers (exposed group) = 10 per 1000 • Incidence rate in non-smokers (unexposed group) = 1 per 1000 Substituting into the formula: AR=10-1/10 = 9/10 = 0.9 This means that 90% of the lung cancer cases among smokers can be attributed to smoking. Incorrect Options: • A. 10%: This is incorrect because the correct attributable risk is 90%, not 10%. • C. 1%: This is incorrect because the incidence rate of lung cancer in non-smokers is much lower than that in smokers, and the attributable risk is not 1%. • D. 100%: This is incorrect because smoking does not cause all cases of lung cancer. Even among smokers, there are other factors that can contribute to the disease, so it cannot be 100%

questions.text: In a case-control study of a suspected association between breast cancer & contraceptive pill, all of following are true statement except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The attributable risk of breast cancer resulting from the pill may be directly measured. In a case-control study, the focus is on identifying an association between an exposure (in this case, the contraceptive pill) and an outcome (breast cancer). However, attributable risk cannot be directly measured in a case-control study because this study design is retrospective and does not follow participants over time. Attributable risk requires the ability to measure the incidence of the disease in both exposed and unexposed groups, which is typically done in a cohort study. Case-control studies estimate odds ratios, not attributable risk, so this statement is incorrect. Incorrect Options: A. The control should come from a population that has the same potential for breast cancer as the cases: This is correct. In a case-control study, the control group should ideally come from the same population as the cases and have the same potential to develop breast cancer, apart from the exposure (contraceptive pill) being studied. This ensures that the observed differences between cases and controls can be attributed to the exposure rather than differences in the underlying risk of the disease. B. The control should not exclude women known to be taking the pill at the time of the survey: This is correct. In a case-control study, the control group should reflect the broader population from which the cases arise, meaning women who are taking the contraceptive pill should not be excluded from the control group. Excluding women on the pill would lead to biased controls and invalidate the comparison between exposed and non-exposed groups. C. All the controls need not be healthy but should not suffer from breast carcinoma: This is correct. Controls do not need to be completely healthy, but they must not have the disease being studied, in this case, breast cancer. The controls can have other conditions or diseases, but they should not have the outcome of interest (breast cancer), which allows for an appropriate comparison with the cases.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about “cohort study”?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Done when incidence of disease is very low among exposed. A cohort study is designed to follow a group of people over time, comparing those exposed to a certain factor with those not exposed, to observe differences in disease incidence. The study is most useful when there is a reasonable level of disease occurrence in the exposed group, which makes it easier to observe and measure the effect of the exposure. If the incidence of disease is very low among the exposed, it may take an impractically long time to see sufficient cases, making the study less efficient. Incorrect Options: A. Provides incidence of disease: This is true. Cohort studies are particularly valuable for calculating the incidence rate of a disease in both exposed and unexposed groups. By following participants over time, researchers can observe how many new cases of the disease develop, providing direct information on incidence. B. Indicated when there is good evidence of association between exposure and disease: This is true. Cohort studies are often performed when there is strong evidence or suspicion of an association between an exposure and a disease, and the goal is to further investigate or confirm the relationship over time. D. Done when ample funds are available: This is true. Cohort studies can be resource-intensive, requiring significant financial and logistical support, especially if they involve large sample sizes or long follow-up periods. Ample funding ensures that researchers can collect the necessary data and follow participants over time.

questions.text: Relative risk of a disease measures the
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Strength of association between suspected cause and effect. Relative risk (RR) is a measure used in cohort studies to compare the risk of a disease or outcome between two groups: those exposed to a particular risk factor and those who are not. It quantifies the strength of the association between the exposure and the disease, indicating how much more likely the exposed group is to develop the disease compared to the unexposed group. Incorrect Options: B. Biological plausibility between suspected cause and effect: This is incorrect because biological plausibility refers to whether the association between the exposure and disease makes sense based on existing biological or medical knowledge. It is not directly measured by relative risk. C. Temporal relationship between suspected cause and effect: This is incorrect. Although temporal relationship is an important factor in determining causality (the exposure must precede the outcome), relative risk itself does not measure the timing of the exposure or disease. However, cohort studies, which often use relative risk, can establish temporal relationships because they track participants over time. D. Specificity of association between suspected cause and effect: This is incorrect because specificity of association refers to how specific an exposure is to a particular disease (i.e., whether the exposure only causes one disease). Relative risk measures the strength of the association but not its specificity.

questions.text: The association between low birth weight and maternal smoking during pregnancy can be studied by obtaining smoking histories of women at the time of their visit and then subsequently following up with birth weight. What type of study is this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Prospective. This study involves collecting smoking histories from women during pregnancy (a baseline exposure) and then following up with the birth weight of their infants later on. This type of study is classified as prospective because it follows participants over time from exposure to outcome. In this case, the researchers are observing the effect of maternal smoking on birth weight, tracking the development of birth weight as an outcome after assessing exposure. Incorrect Options: A. Clinical trial: This is incorrect. A clinical trial involves actively intervening or manipulating the exposure to assess the effect on an outcome. In this case, the study is observational, not experimental, as the researchers are not controlling or intervening with maternal smoking. B. Cross Sectional: This is incorrect. A cross-sectional study observes both the exposure and outcome at the same point in time, rather than following participants over time. Here, the researchers are tracking the exposure (smoking during pregnancy) and its outcome (birth weight) over a period, so it's not cross-sectional. D. Case-Control: This is incorrect. A case-control study typically starts with individuals who have a disease (cases) and compares them to those who do not have the disease (controls), looking back in time to identify potential exposures. This study, however, starts with women who are pregnant (without focusing on disease status) and follows them forward in time to assess birth weight outcomes.

questions.text: False about RCTs is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Randomization is done while selecting subjects for study. In Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs), randomization is the process by which participants are randomly assigned to different treatment groups (e.g., experimental or control groups) after they have been selected for the study, not during the selection process. The goal of randomization is to reduce bias and ensure that each participant has an equal chance of being assigned to any of the treatment groups, thereby improving the validity of the results. Incorrect Options: A. Results of attrition are included in the analysis: This is true. In an RCT, results from participants who drop out or withdraw from the study (attrition) are typically included in the analysis. However, statistical methods are often used to account for the missing data, so the results are still valid and reflect the complete picture of the study's findings. C. Double blinding is most common form of blinding observed: This is true. In RCTs, double blinding (where both the participants and the researchers do not know which treatment the participant is receiving) is a common form of blinding. This helps reduce bias in both the administration of the intervention and the measurement of outcomes. D. Cross-over design helps removing ethical concerns: This is true. In a cross-over design, participants receive both the treatment and the control (or alternative treatment) in a random order, with a washout period in between. This design can help address ethical concerns because it allows participants to serve as their own controls, ensuring that no one is deprived of potential benefit.

questions.text: Nested case control study is at type of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Prospective study. A nested case-control study is a type of study where a case-control study is conducted within the context of a prospective cohort study. In this type of study, participants are initially enrolled and followed over time (prospective), and the cases (those who develop the disease) and controls (those who do not develop the disease) are selected from within the cohort after the follow-up period. This approach allows researchers to study the association between an exposure and a disease outcome using pre-collected data from a cohort study, while still benefiting from the efficiency of a case-control study design. Incorrect Options: A. Retrospective study: This is incorrect because while a nested case-control study uses data that has been collected prospectively, the actual analysis is conducted retrospectively, looking back at the outcomes after the exposure has occurred. However, the key feature is the cohort study’s prospective design. C. Descriptive study: This is incorrect. A descriptive study is focused on describing the distribution and characteristics of a disease or condition in a population, without focusing on the relationship between exposure and outcome. A nested case-control study is more analytical, as it examines associations between exposure and disease. D. Cross-sectional study: This is incorrect. A cross-sectional study observes and analyzes data at one point in time, whereas a nested case-control study follows a cohort over time, looking for the development of disease in relation to exposure.

questions.text: Which of following statements is false about nested case control study?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Is a cohort study nested in a case control study. A nested case-control study is not a cohort study nested in a case-control study. Instead, it is a case-control study nested within a cohort study. In this design, data from an ongoing cohort study are used, and cases (individuals who develop the disease) and controls (individuals who do not develop the disease) are selected from within that cohort after follow-up. The advantage of this design is that it allows for a more efficient use of resources, as the cohort study already has the data on exposure before the disease develops, reducing the need for additional data collection. Incorrect Options: B. It maintains temporal association: This is true. Because the nested case-control study is conducted within the framework of a cohort study, it retains the temporal association between exposure and outcome, meaning the exposure is measured before the disease occurs, which is crucial for determining causality. C. Is useful for rare diseases with expensive diagnostic tests: This is true. A nested case-control study is particularly useful for studying rare diseases because it allows researchers to focus on those individuals who developed the disease (cases) from the cohort, without needing to analyze the entire cohort. This is more efficient, especially when diagnostic tests for the disease are expensive or invasive. D. Recall bias is not seen: This is true. In a nested case-control study, exposure data is typically collected prospectively as part of the cohort study before the outcome (disease) occurs. Therefore, since exposure is measured before the disease develops, the risk of recall bias (where participants may inaccurately recall past exposures) is minimized, unlike in traditional case-control studies where exposure information is often gathered retrospectively.

questions.text: A total of 5000 patients of glaucoma are identified and surveyed by patient interviews regarding family history of glaucoma. Such a study design is called :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Case series report. A case series report involves the collection and analysis of data from a group of individuals with a particular disease or condition, in this case, glaucoma. In a case series, the researcher looks at a group of patients with the disease and collects data on various factors, such as family history or other variables. There is no comparison group, which differentiates a case series from a case-control study or cohort study. Incorrect Options: B. Case-control study: This is incorrect. A case-control study compares individuals with a disease (cases) to individuals without the disease (controls), looking retrospectively at their exposure history (e.g., family history of glaucoma). This study design requires a control group, which is not described in the scenario. C. Clinical trial: This is incorrect. A clinical trial involves an experimental intervention (e.g., a new treatment) to evaluate its effectiveness. The study described does not involve any intervention or experiment, but rather an observational survey of a specific group of patients. D. Cohort study: This is incorrect. While this study mentions the identification of patients with glaucoma, it doesn't describe any follow-up or longitudinal observation to track future outcomes, making it not a cohort study
