Risk difference between exposed and non-exposed

questions.text: Attributable risk means:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Risk difference between exposed and non-exposed. Attributable risk (AR) refers to the difference in the incidence of disease between the exposed and non-exposed groups. It indicates the amount of the disease incidence in the exposed group that can be attributed to the exposure. This is a measure of how much the exposure contributes to the occurrence of the disease in the exposed population. The formula for attributable risk is: AR=Incidence in exposed group - Incidence in unexposed group Incorrect Options: A. Fatality of a disease: This is incorrect. Fatality refers to the proportion of individuals who die from a specific disease among those diagnosed with it, often referred to as case fatality rate (CFR), but this is not related to attributable risk. B. Disease risk ratio between exposed and non-exposed: This is incorrect. Risk ratio (also called relative risk) compares the incidence of disease between the exposed and non-exposed groups, but it is not the same as attributable risk. Attributable risk specifically looks at the difference in disease risk between these groups, not the ratio. D. Communicability of a disease: This is incorrect. Communicability refers to the ability of a disease to spread from person to person, which is unrelated to attributable risk. Attributable risk deals with the impact of exposure on disease risk, not transmission.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about cohort study?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Associated with antecedent causation. A cohort study is a type of prospective study where individuals are followed over time to assess the development of a disease based on their exposure to certain risk factors. It helps in understanding antecedent causation, which refers to identifying factors (like exposure to a risk factor) that precede (or cause) the development of a disease. This is because cohort studies track participants forward in time to see how exposure leads to outcomes. Incorrect Options: A. Disease to risk factor study: This is incorrect. A cohort study is not about studying the disease to the risk factor; rather, it involves tracking individuals based on their exposure (the risk factor) and observing whether they develop the disease. In contrast, a case-control study is about looking backward from the disease (case) to the potential risk factors. B. Effect to cause study: This is incorrect. A cohort study is about examining the cause (exposure) and its potential effect (disease). It is not an "effect to cause" study. The cohort study starts with individuals based on their exposure status and looks forward to observe the disease outcome. "Effect to cause" would be more appropriate for certain experimental studies or reverse causal models. C. Not associated with attributable risk: This is incorrect. Cohort studies are in fact very much associated with attributable risk because they allow researchers to calculate the difference in disease incidence between exposed and unexposed individuals. Attributable risk is a key measure derived from cohort studies, which shows how much of the disease in the exposed group can be attributed to the exposure.

questions.text: Recall bias is most commonly associated with
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Case control study. Recall bias occurs when there is a difference in the accuracy or completeness of the recollection of past events or exposures between the study groups, which can lead to distorted findings. It is most commonly associated with case-control studies because in these studies, participants are asked to recall past exposures or behaviors after the disease (or condition) has already occurred. Individuals with the disease (cases) may remember or report exposures differently from individuals without the disease (controls), leading to potential bias in the results. Incorrect Options: B. Cohort study: This is incorrect. Cohort studies are typically prospective, meaning exposure is measured before the outcome occurs, reducing the likelihood of recall bias. Since participants are followed over time, exposure data is collected before disease development, so there is less reliance on participants' memory. C. Randomized controlled trial (RCT): This is incorrect. RCTs are experimental studies where participants are randomly assigned to different intervention groups. Since exposure is controlled and assigned by the researcher (e.g., receiving a drug or placebo), there is little to no reliance on recall, so recall bias is not a major issue in this type of study. D. Cross-sectional study: This is incorrect. Cross-sectional studies collect data at one point in time, typically focusing on the prevalence of a disease or condition and associated factors. Recall bias could still occur if the study involves retrospective reporting of exposures, but it is less of an issue compared to case-control studies

questions.text: A person wants to study a disease ‘X’ and fat consumption. He collected data for a number of people affected with ‘X’ from the government hospital and details of fat consumption from food industry. This type of study is known as:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ecological study. An ecological study is a type of observational study in which data is collected and analyzed at the population level rather than the individual level. In this case, the researcher is comparing data on the disease "X" from a government hospital (likely at a population level) and fat consumption from the food industry (which represents a broader, population-level dietary trend). This combination of aggregated data from different sources fits the definition of an ecological study. Explanation of the incorrect responses: A. Experimental study: This is incorrect. An experimental study involves the researcher intervening in the study population, such as assigning an intervention or treatment and observing the outcomes. In the given scenario, the researcher is merely collecting existing data and not implementing any intervention, so it is not an experimental study. C. Physiological study: This is incorrect. A physiological study focuses on understanding the biological or physical mechanisms of a disease or condition within individuals, often through laboratory-based or clinical tests. The study described does not involve physiological measurements, so this is not the correct choice. D. Cross-sectional study: This is incorrect. A cross-sectional study involves collecting data at a single point in time to assess the prevalence of a disease or risk factor. While the study described collects data, it is not focused on a snapshot in time, but rather on data from different sources (hospital and food industry), so it doesn't strictly fit the definition of a cross-sectional study.

questions.text: Case control study is used for study of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) All of these. A case-control study is a type of observational study design that is particularly useful for studying diseases of all types, including common, known, and rare diseases. In a case-control study, individuals with the disease (cases) are compared to individuals without the disease (controls), and the researcher looks backward to determine the exposure status of both groups. This makes it a versatile study design for a wide range of diseases, regardless of how common or rare they are. Incorrect Options: A. Common diseases: While case-control studies are indeed useful for studying common diseases, they are not limited to only those diseases. They can be used for a wide range of diseases, not just common ones. B. Known diseases: This is not fully correct. While case-control studies can certainly be used for known diseases, they are also valuable for investigating unknown or less understood diseases. They allow researchers to investigate associations between risk factors and diseases, even if the disease is not well-known or well-understood yet. C. Rare diseases: This is correct in part, but not the full picture. Case-control studies are particularly valuable for studying rare diseases because the researcher can focus on a relatively small group of cases, which might not be large enough for other study designs, such as cohort studies, to be feasible. However, case-control studies are not limited to rare diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a true difference between Case control and Cohort study?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Case Control study requires more time than cohort study. A. Case Control study requires more time than cohort study: This statement is false. Typically, cohort studies require more time than case-control studies. In a cohort study, participants are followed over time to observe the occurrence of a disease or outcome, which can take years. In contrast, case-control studies are retrospective, meaning data on exposures and outcomes are collected after the disease has already occurred, making them quicker to conduct. Therefore, case-control studies generally require less time than cohort studies, not more. Incorrect Options: B. Cohorts are chosen based on exposure in a cohort study: This is true. In a cohort study, participants are selected based on their exposure status (exposed or not exposed to a risk factor) and are then followed over time to observe the development of disease. Cohorts are defined by the presence or absence of the exposure, not by the disease status. C. Cohort study is generally prospective in direction: This is true. Cohort studies are typically prospective, meaning that researchers follow participants forward in time to assess the outcomes (such as the development of a disease) based on the exposure they had at the start of the study. D. Case control study must be used for rare diseases: This is true. Case-control studies are particularly useful for studying rare diseases because they start with individuals who already have the disease (cases) and compare them with individuals who do not have the disease (controls). This approach allows researchers to gather enough cases of a rare disease, which would be difficult to do with a cohort study, where the disease may be too rare to observe in a reasonable time frame.

questions.text: Case- control study is a type of :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Analytical study. A case-control study is a type of analytical study because it is designed to investigate the relationship between an exposure and an outcome (in this case, a disease). In a case-control study, individuals who have the disease (cases) are compared with individuals who do not have the disease (controls) to identify potential risk factors or exposures that may be associated with the disease. This allows researchers to analyze the association between exposure and disease. Incorrect Options: A. Descriptive epidemiological study: This is incorrect. Descriptive studies are primarily concerned with describing the occurrence of diseases or health outcomes in populations, often in terms of time, place, and person (e.g., incidence, prevalence). They do not aim to analyze relationships between exposures and outcomes. Case-control studies, on the other hand, are designed to analyze associations, making them analytical rather than descriptive. C. Longitudinal study: This is incorrect. A longitudinal study involves following participants over a period of time to observe the development of outcomes based on exposures. Case-control studies, in contrast, are retrospective and do not follow participants over time. They collect data after the outcome has already occurred. D. Experimental study: This is incorrect. Experimental studies, such as randomized controlled trials (RCTs), involve the researcher manipulating exposures or interventions and measuring their effects on outcomes. Case-control studies are observational in nature and do not involve intervention or manipulation by the researcher, so they are not experimental studies.

questions.text: As compared to a routine case control study nested case control study avoids problems ( in study design) related to :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Temporal association. A nested case-control study is a specific type of case-control study that is conducted within a cohort study. It involves selecting cases (individuals who develop the outcome of interest) and controls (individuals who do not develop the outcome) from a pre-existing cohort that has already been followed over time. This design helps in addressing issues like temporal association because the exposure data is collected before the outcome occurs, which maintains the correct temporal sequence (exposure precedes the disease). Incorrect Options: B. Confounding bias: This is not fully correct. While a nested case-control study may help reduce some sources of bias, it does not entirely eliminate confounding bias. Confounding occurs when a third variable is associated with both the exposure and the outcome, which is not automatically addressed by the study design. Confounding still needs to be controlled for in the analysis phase. C. Need for a long follow-up: This is incorrect. In a nested case-control study, the follow-up is usually done as part of the original cohort study, so the follow-up time is still required. However, a nested case-control study may be more efficient than a full cohort study because it focuses on a smaller sample (cases and controls), reducing the need for long follow-up in the study itself. D. Randomization: This is incorrect. Randomization refers to the process of randomly assigning participants to different groups (e.g., treatment or control) in experimental studies, such as randomized controlled trials (RCTs). Since a nested case-control study is observational and not experimental, it does not involve randomization. Randomization is not a feature of case-control studies.

questions.text: Cross sectional study is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Prevalence study. A cross-sectional study is designed to collect data at a single point in time or over a short period, assessing the prevalence of a disease or condition in a population. It provides a snapshot of the health status of a group of individuals at a particular moment. Since it looks at the proportion of people affected by a disease or condition at one point, it is referred to as a prevalence study. Incorrect Options: A. Longitudinal study: This is incorrect. A longitudinal study involves repeated observations of the same individuals over a longer period, often to study how exposures affect outcomes over time. Cross-sectional studies do not follow individuals over time; they collect data at one point, so they are not considered longitudinal. B. Prospective study: This is incorrect. A prospective study involves following participants over time to observe outcomes based on exposures. In contrast, cross-sectional studies assess participants at a single point in time, making them not prospective. C. Retrospective study: This is incorrect. A retrospective study looks backward in time, often using existing records or data to examine past exposures and outcomes. While a cross-sectional study can sometimes use existing data, it does not focus on past events or look backward in time. It simply measures the presence or absence of outcomes at a specific point in time.

questions.text: True about case control study is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Attributable risk cannot be calculated. In a case-control study, the focus is on comparing individuals with a disease (cases) to those without the disease (controls) to identify risk factors. However, because case-control studies are retrospective and do not follow participants over time, attributable risk (the proportion of disease cases in the exposed group that can be attributed to the exposure) cannot be directly calculated. Attributable risk requires data on the incidence of disease in both exposed and unexposed groups, which is typically only available in prospective studies (such as cohort studies). Incorrect Options: A. Not possible for rare disease: This is incorrect. Case-control studies are actually ideal for studying rare diseases because they start with cases (those with the disease) and work backward to identify potential risk factors. This design helps to efficiently study diseases that occur infrequently in the population. B. Odds ratio cannot be calculated: This is incorrect. Odds ratio (OR) is a key measure in case-control studies. It compares the odds of exposure in the cases to the odds of exposure in the controls, making it a useful statistic for analyzing the strength of association between an exposure and an outcome in a case-control study. D. Bias is not seen: This is incorrect. Case-control studies are prone to various biases, including recall bias (where participants may not accurately remember past exposures) and selection bias (if cases and controls are not properly matched or chosen). While bias can be minimized with careful study design and analysis, it is never entirely absent from case-control studies.

questions.text: What is not true about cross sectional study?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tells aetiology. A cross-sectional study is designed to provide a snapshot of the health status or characteristics of a population at a particular point in time. While it can describe patterns of disease and measure the prevalence of conditions, it does not establish cause-and-effect relationships or determine the etiology (causes) of diseases. It is limited in identifying aetiology because it does not observe participants over time or consider temporal relationships between exposure and outcome. Incorrect Options: A. Also called prevalence study: This is true. A cross-sectional study is often called a prevalence study because it measures the prevalence of a disease or condition in a population at a single point in time. It helps to quantify how common a condition is in a defined population. C. Shows pattern of disease: This is true. Cross-sectional studies are useful in identifying the pattern of disease in a population, including which groups are more or less affected by a certain condition. By examining data at one point, you can observe trends and distributions of disease within different demographics or geographic regions. D. Snapshot of a population: This is true. A cross-sectional study is essentially a snapshot of a population, capturing information about individuals' health status, behaviors, exposures, and other characteristics at one point in time. It does not track changes over time.

questions.text: Healthy worker effect is bias of which type?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Selection bias. The healthy worker effect is a type of selection bias that occurs when individuals who are part of a study population (such as workers) are healthier than the general population. This happens because people who are sick or have severe health conditions are less likely to be employed or remain in the workforce. As a result, studies comparing worker populations to the general population may underestimate the true association between the exposure and health outcomes, as the worker group tends to be healthier. Incorrect Options: B. Recall bias: Recall bias occurs when study participants have inaccurate or selective recollections of past events or exposures. This type of bias is typically seen in case-control studies, where participants are asked to recall past exposures. Healthy worker effect is not related to recall issues but to selection of participants. C. Confounding bias: Confounding bias occurs when the effect of the exposure on the outcome is mixed with the effect of an additional factor, leading to a distortion of the true association. While healthy worker effect could lead to confounding in certain situations, it is primarily considered a type of selection bias rather than a confounding issue. D. Berkesonian bias: Berkson’s bias is a type of selection bias that occurs when the study population is selected from a hospital or clinical setting, leading to an overrepresentation of people with certain conditions. This is different from the healthy worker effect, which involves the selection of a healthier population for the study.

questions.text: True about cross-sectional study is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Chronic diseases can be studied. A cross-sectional study is particularly useful for studying the prevalence of chronic diseases, as it allows researchers to capture data on the health status of a population at a single point in time. This type of study is well-suited for examining how common chronic conditions (such as diabetes, hypertension, or asthma) are in a population. Chronic diseases are often more prevalent and can be measured across different demographic groups, making cross-sectional studies ideal for assessing patterns of chronic conditions. Incorrect Options: A. Suitable for study of rare diseases: This is incorrect. Cross-sectional studies are generally not suitable for studying rare diseases. Since they rely on data collected at a single point in time, finding enough cases of a rare disease within the study population is challenging. Case-control studies or cohort studies are better suited for studying rare diseases. C. Involves few numbers of subjects: This is incorrect. Cross-sectional studies do not necessarily involve a small number of subjects. The study size can vary depending on the scope and objective of the research. They often involve larger sample sizes to accurately represent the population and detect patterns or associations. D. Most inexpensive study: This is incorrect. While cross-sectional studies can be more affordable compared to some other types of studies (like randomized controlled trials), they are not necessarily the most inexpensive. The cost of a cross-sectional study depends on the data collection method and sample size. Some studies may involve extensive data gathering, making them relatively expensive.

questions.text: Bias due to inter- observer variation is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Observation bias. Observation bias (also known as inter-observer bias) occurs when there are differences in how data is observed or recorded by different individuals (observers) or instruments. In situations where multiple observers are involved in collecting data, variations in their interpretations or measurements can lead to inconsistency. This bias can affect the validity of the study, as results may be influenced by who is doing the observing rather than the true characteristics of the subjects. Incorrect Options: A. Selection bias: Selection bias occurs when the process of selecting participants or data points for a study leads to a sample that is not representative of the target population. This type of bias affects the generalizability of the results, but it is not related to differences in how observations are made by different individuals. B. Sampling bias: Sampling bias refers to a situation where the sample chosen for the study is not representative of the entire population. It is a form of bias that occurs during the sampling process, rather than during the observation or data collection stage. It does not specifically concern differences between observers in recording or measuring data. D. Recall bias: Recall bias occurs when participants in a study have inaccurate or selective memories about past events or exposures, leading to systematic errors in the data. This type of bias is related to participants' ability to recall information rather than how observations are made by researchers or observers.

questions.text: Hospital based study among following is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Case control study. A hospital-based study is often a case-control study, where researchers compare patients (cases) with a certain disease or condition to those without it (controls) from the same hospital or clinic setting. The goal is to assess the association between exposure factors and disease development. In this context, the cases (patients with the disease) are compared with controls (patients without the disease), often from the same hospital, which makes it a hospital-based study. Incorrect Options: A. Cohort: A cohort study is typically a prospective study that follows a group of individuals over time to observe how different exposures affect the incidence of a particular outcome or disease. While it can be hospital-based, a cohort study usually involves following patients or participants over time, not comparing cases and controls retrospectively. C. Cross sectional: A cross-sectional study collects data from a population at a single point in time to measure the prevalence of a disease or exposure. While it can be conducted in a hospital setting, it does not specifically involve comparing cases to controls, as in a case-control study. D. Ecological study: An ecological study analyzes population-level data (such as data about a country or region) rather than individual-level data. It is not typically a hospital-based study, as it focuses on groups or populations, not individual patients or cases from a hospital.

questions.text: Study of alcohol intake for 10 year and occurring of hepatic disease type of study is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cohort. A cohort study is a type of longitudinal study where a group of individuals (the cohort) is followed over a period of time to observe the development of specific outcomes, such as diseases or conditions. In this case, the study involves tracking alcohol intake over 10 years and the occurrence of hepatic disease, which fits the definition of a cohort study. This study looks at a group of people with different levels of alcohol intake and follows them over time to see how it affects the occurrence of hepatic disease. Incorrect Options: B. Case control: A case-control study is a retrospective study where researchers start by identifying people who already have the disease (cases) and those who do not (controls). They then look backward to examine past exposures (such as alcohol intake). Since this study is looking at alcohol intake and hepatic disease over a future time frame, it does not fit the case-control design, which is more focused on studying the past exposures of already diseased individuals. C. Random: A random study likely refers to random sampling or randomization, which is not a specific study design in itself. Randomization is a technique used in experimental studies like randomized controlled trials (RCTs) to assign participants to different treatment or control groups. This is not applicable to a study that tracks alcohol intake over time. D. Cross-sectional: A cross-sectional study collects data at a single point in time, providing a snapshot of a population to examine the relationship between exposures and outcomes. Since this study follows participants over 10 years to observe the development of hepatic disease, it is not a cross-sectional study.

questions.text: Matching is done to remove:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Confounding factors. Matching is a technique used in observational studies, particularly in case-control studies, to control for confounding. Confounders are variables that are related to both the exposure and the outcome, which can distort or mask the true relationship between the two. By matching participants on certain characteristics (such as age, sex, or other potential confounders), researchers ensure that the groups being compared (such as cases and controls) are similar in those key aspects. This helps isolate the effect of the exposure on the outcome, reducing the impact of confounding factors. Incorrect Options: B. Selection bias: While matching can help control for confounders, it does not directly address selection bias. Selection bias occurs when the way participants are selected for a study leads to an unrepresentative sample. Matching focuses on controlling for confounders, not on how participants are selected. C. Observation bias: Observation bias (or measurement bias) occurs when the way data is collected leads to inaccuracies. Matching does not directly control for observation bias, which involves how information is measured or observed during the study. D. Sampling error: Sampling error refers to the natural variability that occurs when a sample is not perfectly representative of the population. Matching does not eliminate sampling error, as it does not change the inherent randomness of sample selection.

choices.text: Relative risk, attributable risk, population attributable risk
Incidence, Relative risk, and attributable risk

questions.text: Case control study estimate:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Only odd’s ratio. A case-control study is a type of observational study where participants are selected based on the presence (cases) or absence (controls) of a specific outcome or disease. The primary measure used in case-control studies is the odds ratio (OR), which estimates the odds of exposure in the cases compared to the odds of exposure in the controls. The odds ratio helps determine whether an exposure is associated with a higher or lower likelihood of the disease or outcome under study. Incorrect Options: B. Odds ratio and attributable risk: While odds ratio is a key measure in a case-control study, attributable risk cannot be directly calculated in case-control studies. Attributable risk refers to the difference in disease rates between exposed and unexposed individuals, which is a measure typically derived from cohort studies, not case-control studies. C. Relative risk, attributable risk, population attributable risk: Relative risk (RR), attributable risk, and population attributable risk are measures generally used in cohort studies or clinical trials, not in case-control studies. Case-control studies cannot directly calculate relative risk because they are retrospective, meaning the disease has already occurred by the time of the study. D. Incidence, Relative risk, and attributable risk: Incidence refers to the rate of new cases of a disease, and relative risk and attributable risk are measures used in cohort studies or experimental designs. Case-control studies cannot directly measure incidence or relative risk, as they do not follow subjects over time; they only compare exposures between diseased (cases) and non-diseased (controls) individuals.

questions.text: Which of these is the best study design to assess in quickest time the association between smoking and lung cancer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Case control study. A case-control study is the best design to assess the association between smoking and lung cancer in the quickest time because it is a retrospective study. In a case-control study, researchers identify individuals who already have the disease (cases) and compare them to individuals without the disease (controls). By looking back at their past exposures (in this case, smoking), researchers can quickly identify if smoking is more common among those with lung cancer compared to those without. Incorrect Options: B. Cohort study: A cohort study is typically prospective, meaning that researchers follow participants over time to observe who develops the disease. This type of study takes more time to complete since it requires tracking the participants for a significant period to observe the onset of lung cancer. Although cohort studies provide valuable data, they take longer and are not ideal when you need quick results. C. Cross-sectional study: A cross-sectional study measures exposure and outcome at the same time, providing a snapshot of the population. While it can show an association between smoking and lung cancer, it cannot establish a temporal relationship (i.e., whether smoking caused lung cancer), and it may not be the best design for a causal association. It also doesn’t provide the best way to study rare diseases like lung cancer because the disease may not be prevalent enough in the sample. D. Randomized controlled trial (RCT): RCTs are considered the gold standard for assessing causality, but they are not ideal for studying the association between smoking and lung cancer. It would be unethical and impractical to randomly assign people to smoke or not smoke for the purpose of studying cancer risk. Additionally, RCTs take a long time to set up and collect data, so they are not suited for studying an association in a short timeframe.

choices.text: The patients do not know which treatment they are receiving
The patients do not know that they are in a drug trial

questions.text: In a double blind clinical drug trial:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The patients do not know which treatment they are receiving. In a double-blind clinical drug trial, both the patients and the researchers are unaware of which treatment (active drug or placebo) the participants are receiving. This design helps to minimize bias in the results by preventing both observer bias (where the researcher's expectations might influence their assessment of outcomes) and participant bias (where the patient's expectations could affect how they report their symptoms or responses). Incorrect Options: A. Each patient receives a placebo: This is not always true. In a double-blind trial, some patients receive the active drug and others receive a placebo (a substance with no therapeutic effect), but not all patients necessarily receive a placebo. The trial is designed to compare the effects of the drug against the placebo to assess the drug's efficacy. B. Each patient receives both (double) treatments: This is incorrect. Patients do not receive both treatments. In a double-blind trial, participants are assigned either the treatment or the placebo, not both. If both treatments were given, it would be a crossover trial, not a double-blind trial. D. The patients do not know that they are in a drug trial: This is not true either. In a double-blind trial, the patients know they are participating in a clinical trial, but they do not know which specific treatment they are receiving (active drug vs. placebo). Therefore, the statement is misleading.

questions.text: All the following are true in a randomized control trial (RCT) except :-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The dropouts from the trial should be excluded from the analysis. In a randomized controlled trial (RCT), dropouts (those who leave the study before completion) should not automatically be excluded from the analysis. There are specific methods such as intention-to-treat analysis that include all participants, even those who dropped out. This helps to avoid bias that could result from excluding participants, ensuring that the final results reflect the impact of the intervention on the population as a whole. Incorrect Options: A. Baseline characteristics of intervention are similar in both arms: This is true. In a randomized controlled trial, participants are randomly assigned to either the treatment group (intervention) or the control group. Randomization ensures that the baseline characteristics of the two groups are similar, which minimizes the risk of confounding factors influencing the results. B. Investigator’s bias is minimized by double blinding: This is true. Double blinding means that neither the participants nor the investigators know which group (intervention or control) the participants belong to. This reduces bias from both the investigator (who might consciously or unconsciously influence the treatment process) and the participant (who might have expectations that influence their responses). C. The sample size required depends on the hypothesis: This is true. The required sample size in an RCT is calculated based on the hypothesis, which includes factors such as the expected effect size, the desired power of the study, and the significance level (alpha). This ensures that the study has enough participants to detect a meaningful difference if one exists.

choices.text: Its permit an ethical alternative for patients who do not wish to be subjected to an experimental treatment.
It allows larger numbers of patients to be used, thus increasing the power of the statistical techniques used
It helps to eliminate alternative explanations for the results of the study
It reduces the likelihood of making a type II error in hypothesis testing

questions.text: What is the purpose of a control group in an experimental study?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) It helps to eliminate alternative explanations for the results of the study. In an experimental study, a control group serves as a baseline against which the outcomes of the experimental group can be compared. By having a control group that does not receive the experimental treatment (or receives a placebo), researchers can isolate the effect of the intervention itself. This comparison helps eliminate alternative explanations (e.g., natural progression of disease, psychological factors, or other treatments) for the results observed in the experimental group. Incorrect Options: A. Its permit an ethical alternative for patients who do not wish to be subjected to an experimental treatment: While this is a concern in ethical studies, the purpose of the control group is not primarily to provide an ethical alternative for unwilling participants. The control group’s main role is to provide a valid comparison for the experimental group. B. It allows larger numbers of patients to be used, thus increasing the power of the statistical techniques used: The power of the study is indeed influenced by sample size, but the control group itself does not directly increase the number of patients. Randomization and sample size calculations are the primary methods used to increase statistical power, not the inclusion of a control group alone. D. It reduces the likelihood of making a type II error in hypothesis testing: A type II error (failing to reject a false null hypothesis) can be reduced by increasing statistical power, which is influenced by sample size and the effect size. While the control group helps with accurate comparisons, its primary purpose is not specifically to reduce type II errors.

choices.text: To equalize the effects of extraneous variables, thus guarding against bias
To allow inferential statistics to be used

questions.text: What is the purpose of randomization in a clinical trial?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) To equalize the effects of extraneous variables, thus guarding against bias. Randomization in a clinical trial is primarily used to equalize the effects of extraneous (or confounding) variables between the treatment and control groups. This helps ensure that the groups are comparable at the start of the study and that the observed outcomes are due to the intervention being tested rather than other factors. By randomizing participants, the study design helps reduce bias and ensure that any differences in outcomes between groups are likely due to the treatment itself rather than other confounding factors. Incorrect Options: B. To allow inferential statistics to be used: While randomization does facilitate the use of inferential statistics, the main reason for randomization is to balance the groups and reduce bias. Inferential statistics can be used in both randomized and non-randomized studies, but randomization enhances the validity of the statistical conclusions. C. To guard against placebo effects: While placebo effects can influence the results of a trial, randomization is not directly used to guard against them. The use of a placebo group or blinding is more directly aimed at controlling for placebo effects. Randomization helps ensure that the placebo group and the experimental group are similar at baseline. D. To guard against ethical problems: Randomization itself is not primarily aimed at addressing ethical concerns. Ethical issues are typically managed through informed consent, ethical review boards, and good clinical practice guidelines. However, randomization helps ensure fairness in assigning participants to different treatment groups.

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company develops a new antihypertensive drug. Samples of 24 hypertensive patients, randomly selected from a large population of hypertensive people, are randomly divided into 2 groups of 12. One group is given the new drug over a period of 1 month; the other group is given a placebo according to the same schedule. Neither the patients nor the treating physicians are aware of which patients are in which group. At the end of the month, measurements are made of the patient’s blood pressures. This study:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Is a RCT (Randomized Controlled Trial). This study is a Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT) because: Randomization is used to assign patients to either the treatment (new drug) or the control (placebo) group. The study has a control group (placebo group) and an intervention group (drug group). The study is designed to test the efficacy of a new antihypertensive drug compared to a placebo. The trial uses blinding where both the patients and treating physicians are unaware of which treatment each patient receives, which is referred to as double-blind. Incorrect Options: B. Uses a crossover design: A crossover design involves having participants receive both the treatment and the placebo at different points in time. However, in this study, patients are only assigned to either the treatment or the placebo group for the entire study duration, so it is not a crossover design. C. Is a single-blind experiment: A single-blind experiment is one in which only one group (usually the patients) is unaware of the treatment they are receiving. In this study, both the patients and the physicians are unaware of which treatment the patients are receiving, which makes it a double-blind study, not a single-blind study. D. Is a prospective study: While the study does look at future outcomes (blood pressure after one month of treatment), the term "prospective" refers more to the overall design of the study rather than being specific to randomized controlled trials. An RCT is considered a prospective study, but the key feature in this question is that it is an RCT.

questions.text: Intention- to- treat analysis is done in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Randomized control trials. Intention-to-treat analysis is a principle used primarily in randomized controlled trials (RCTs). It refers to the analysis of data based on the initial treatment assignment rather than the treatment actually received. This method includes all participants who were originally randomized, regardless of whether they completed the treatment or adhered to the assigned intervention. The goal is to prevent bias that may result from excluding participants who drop out or deviate from the assigned treatment. Incorrect Options: A. Cohort study: Cohort studies are observational studies, and while they can use statistical techniques to control for confounders and dropouts, they do not generally use intention-to-treat analysis, which is specific to randomized trials. B. Survival analysis studies: Survival analysis focuses on time-to-event data (such as time to death or disease progression) and is commonly used in studies like clinical trials or cohort studies. While intention-to-treat analysis could be used in a survival analysis study, it is not specifically associated with survival analysis but rather with randomized controlled trials. D. Multiple time series studies: Time series studies examine data points collected at multiple time intervals. These studies generally focus on trends over time, not on randomized treatments, so intention-to-treat analysis does not apply.

choices.text: Help ensure that study subjects are representative of the general population
Ensure that the study groups are comparable on base line characteristics

questions.text: The major purpose of random assignment in a clinical trial is to :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ensure that the study groups are comparable on baseline characteristics. Random assignment is a key feature of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and is used to ensure that the participants in different study groups are as comparable as possible on baseline characteristics. This helps to minimize the potential for bias in the selection of participants, ensuring that any differences between the groups in the outcome can be attributed to the treatment or intervention rather than other confounding factors. Random assignment balances known and unknown factors between the groups, making it a powerful tool for establishing cause-and-effect relationships. Incorrect Options: A. Help ensure that study subjects are representative of the general population: While random sampling (not random assignment) is used to ensure that study subjects are representative of the general population, random assignment is used to ensure that the treatment groups are comparable on baseline characteristics. Random assignment does not necessarily make the study sample representative of the broader population. B. Facilitate double blinding: Double blinding refers to the process where both the participants and the researchers are unaware of the group assignments (treatment or placebo). Random assignment can be used in studies with double blinding, but the purpose of random assignment is not to facilitate blinding, but rather to create comparable groups at the start of the trial. C. Facilitate measurement of outcome variables: Random assignment does not directly facilitate the measurement of outcome variables. Measurement of outcomes depends on the design of the study and the instruments used, not on how participants are assigned to groups.

choices.text: They are useful in studies involving mortality
They use the patient as his or her own control
They are usually easier to interpret than the comparable parallel clinical trial

questions.text: Which one of the following statements regarding pre post clinical trial is most appropriate?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) They use the patient as his or her own control. A pre-post clinical trial is a type of study where measurements or observations are taken before and after an intervention on the same group of participants. This type of design uses each patient as their own control, which helps to reduce the effects of confounding variables, as changes observed can be more directly attributed to the intervention rather than differences between groups. This is particularly helpful when trying to minimize individual variability that might affect the outcome. Incorrect Options: A. They cannot be randomized: This is incorrect because while pre-post designs are often not randomized, they can be randomized in some cases, especially in more complex experimental designs where there might be randomization before the intervention. However, typically, the same group is measured before and after the intervention. B. They are useful in studies involving mortality: This is not necessarily true. Pre-post clinical trials are more commonly used to assess changes in health outcomes such as symptoms, biomarkers, or quality of life, rather than mortality, which typically requires a longer follow-up period and is often studied in randomized controlled trials (RCTs) with larger sample sizes. D. They are usually easier to interpret than the comparable parallel clinical trial: This is not always the case. While pre-post designs have the advantage of using the same participants for both measurements, interpretation can be complicated by factors such as time-related changes or external influences. Parallel clinical trials (where different groups are randomized to different treatments) can sometimes provide clearer comparisons and minimize biases related to time or individual differences.

questions.text: All of the following are Experimental/ Interventional studies except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ecological studies. Ecological studies are not considered experimental or interventional studies. These studies analyze data at the population or group level rather than the individual level. They examine associations between exposures and outcomes at the group level, rather than manipulating an exposure or intervention to observe its effect on individuals. Explanation of the experimental/interventional studies: A. Randomized control trials (RCTs): These are experimental studies in which participants are randomly assigned to different groups (intervention or control) to assess the effect of an intervention or treatment. It is the gold standard for determining causal relationships. B. Field trials: These are interventional studies conducted in a natural setting outside of a clinical setting, typically involving healthy individuals or populations. They are designed to assess the impact of an intervention on the development of disease or other health outcomes. C. Community trials: These are a type of experimental study conducted on groups or communities rather than individuals. The intervention is applied at the community level, such as a public health campaign, to assess its impact on health outcomes.

choices.text: Can’t double blind in animal trials

questions.text: Which is true about experimental trials?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Are always prospective. Experimental trials are typically prospective because they involve following participants (or animals in animal trials) over time to observe the effects of an intervention or treatment. In these studies, the researcher introduces an intervention and observes the outcomes in the future. Hence, experimental trials are always conducted prospectively. Incorrect Options: A. Can’t double blind in animal trials: This is false because it is possible to implement double-blinding in animal trials. Double-blinding means that neither the researcher nor the animal subject knows which treatment is being administered, which can be done in animal experiments. B. All animal trials are unethical: This is not true. Animal trials can be ethical when proper ethical guidelines are followed, such as minimizing suffering and ensuring that the research benefits outweigh the potential harm. C. Can’t do interim analysis: This is false because interim analyses are often conducted in clinical trials (including animal trials) to evaluate the data at certain points during the study, and adjust if necessary, without waiting for the full study to conclude.

questions.text: Selection bias can be eliminated by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Randomization. Randomization is the best method to eliminate selection bias in clinical trials or experiments. It involves randomly assigning participants to different study groups (e.g., treatment vs. control groups). This ensures that each participant has an equal chance of being assigned to any group, thereby reducing the chance that the groups differ systematically in ways that could affect the outcome, thus preventing selection bias. Incorrect Options: B. Single blinding: This refers to the participants not knowing which treatment group they belong to (but the researchers do). While this helps minimize bias in participants’ behavior, it does not eliminate selection bias. Selection bias is more about how participants are assigned to groups. C. Double blinding: This refers to both the participants and the researchers being unaware of the treatment assignments. While double blinding helps reduce other biases, such as performance bias or detection bias, it does not specifically address selection bias. D. Matching: This is a technique used to control for confounding variables by pairing participants with similar characteristics. While matching is useful in observational studies, it does not eliminate selection bias completely like randomization does in experimental studies

choices.text: Observer is blind about the study
Person or groups being observed is blind about the study
Both observer and person or group being observed is blind about the study
Interpreters and analyser are blind about the study

questions.text: Double blind study means:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Both observer and person or group being observed is blind about the study. In a double-blind study, both the researcher (observer) and the participants (person or group being observed) are unaware of which treatment or intervention the participants are receiving. This helps to eliminate bias in both the administration of the treatment and in the evaluation of the results. It is commonly used in clinical trials to ensure that neither the participants' nor the researchers' expectations influence the outcomes. Incorrect Options: A. Observer is blind about the study: This refers to a single-blind study, where only the researcher (or the observer) does not know which treatment the participant is receiving. This still allows the participants to know, which can introduce bias from their expectations. B. Person or group being observed is blind about the study: This also refers to a single-blind study, where the participants do not know which treatment they are receiving, but the researchers know. This does reduce bias from participants but does not eliminate bias from the researchers. D. Interpreters and analyzers are blind about the study: This is an important concept, but it specifically refers to situations where data interpretation or analysis is done without knowledge of the treatment assignment, which can reduce analysis bias, but this is not what defines a double-blind study.

choices.text: Statistical technique for combing finding from several independent studies on special topic
Its purpose is not to identify risk factors
Its purpose is to increase statistical power by increasing sample size
Validity doesn’t depend on quality of systemic review

questions.text: All are true regarding meta-analysis except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Validity doesn’t depend on quality of systematic review. In a meta-analysis, data from several independent studies on a particular topic are combined using a statistical technique. The goal is to synthesize the findings from these studies to reach more robust conclusions and increase statistical power, which is achieved by increasing the total sample size. Incorrect Options: A. Statistical technique for combining findings from several independent studies on a special topic: This is accurate. Meta-analysis is a statistical technique used to aggregate and combine the results of multiple studies to provide a more precise estimate of the effect of an intervention or association. B. Its purpose is not to identify risk factors: This is also true. Meta-analysis typically aims to synthesize existing evidence about a specific effect or relationship but does not directly aim to identify new risk factors. C. Its purpose is to increase statistical power by increasing sample size: This is correct as well. By combining data from multiple studies, meta-analysis increases the overall sample size, thus improving the statistical power to detect an effect or association.

Critical appraisal is always criterion based

questions.text: Not a feature of systematic review?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Meta-analysis always performed. Systematic reviews are designed to provide a comprehensive, unbiased synthesis of all available evidence on a specific research question. However, a meta-analysis (a statistical technique for combining the results of multiple studies) is not always performed in a systematic review. Meta-analysis is typically done if the data across studies are sufficiently similar to be pooled together. Incorrect Options: B. Search for literature is compulsory using explicit search strategy: This is true. A systematic review involves a thorough and explicit search strategy to minimize bias in identifying relevant studies. C. Critical appraisal is always criterion based: This is true. Critical appraisal of the studies included in the review often follows set criteria to assess their quality. D. Research question always focused: This is true. A systematic review is typically conducted to address a specific, well-defined research question.

May be incorrect because of failure to recognize a long – term cohort effect
Incorrect because as no control or comparison group was involved

questions.text: An advertisement in a medical journal stated that 2000 subjects with sore throat were treated with our new medicine. With in 4 days, 94 % were asymptomatic. The advertisement claims that the medicine was effective. Based on the evidence given above, the claim:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Incorrect because no control or comparison group was involved. Explanation: For a claim to be considered valid, especially in the context of a medical treatment's effectiveness, the study or evidence should involve a control or comparison group. This allows for the observation of the effect of the treatment relative to other treatments, a placebo, or no treatment at all. Without this comparison, it is difficult to draw valid conclusions about whether the observed improvement (94% asymptomatic after 4 days) was due to the medicine or due to natural recovery or other factors. Incorrect Options: A. Is correct: This is not true because the absence of a control group makes it difficult to confirm that the improvement was due to the medicine rather than other factors. B. May be incorrect as the conclusion is not based on a rate: This option is misleading. The claim is based on a rate (94% asymptomatic), so the issue isn't about the use of a rate. C. May be incorrect because of failure to recognize a long-term cohort effect: While this could be an issue in some cases, it's not the primary flaw here. The main concern is the absence of a control or comparison group, not the failure to recognize a long-term effect.

questions.text: Of different epidemiological study designs available to test association between risk factor and disease best design is of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cohort study. Explanation: A cohort study is considered one of the best epidemiological study designs to test the association between a risk factor and a disease because it allows for the observation of participants over time. In a cohort study, individuals are grouped based on their exposure to a risk factor (exposed vs. unexposed) and are then followed to see who develops the disease. This design provides a strong ability to infer causal relationships because it tracks the sequence of exposure and outcome over time. Here’s why the other options are less ideal for testing the association between risk factors and disease: A. Case control study: While case-control studies are useful for studying rare diseases, they are retrospective, meaning they look back in time to assess exposure. This makes them more prone to recall bias and cannot establish temporal relationships as strongly as cohort studies. B. Ecological study: Ecological studies examine populations or groups rather than individuals, making it difficult to draw conclusions about individual-level risk factors and disease. These studies are useful for generating hypotheses but have limited ability to prove causal relationships. D. Cross-sectional study: Cross-sectional studies collect data at one point in time, so they are unable to establish a temporal relationship between exposure and disease. They can identify associations but not causality.

questions.text: In establishing causal association, most essential criterion is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Temporal relationship. Explanation: In establishing a causal association, the temporal relationship is the most essential criterion. For a factor to be considered a cause of a disease, the exposure (or risk factor) must precede the onset of the disease. This is the cornerstone of establishing causality because, without temporal precedence, it would be impossible to determine whether the exposure led to the disease or if the disease caused the exposure. Incorrect Options: A. Consistency of relationship: While consistency (the finding of the same association across different studies, populations, or settings) strengthens the evidence for causality, it is not as essential as the temporal relationship. Even consistent findings cannot establish causality if the exposure does not precede the outcome. C. Duration of relationship: The duration of the relationship may be important for understanding how long it takes for an exposure to lead to a disease, but it is not as fundamental as the fact that the exposure must come before the disease. D. Strength of relationship: The strength of the relationship (how strongly the exposure is associated with the disease) can help support causality but is not as critical as demonstrating that the exposure precedes the disease.

questions.text: Suspected cause preceding the observed effect is an example for :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Temporality. Explanation: Temporality refers to the concept that for a causal relationship to exist, the suspected cause must precede the observed effect. This is the cornerstone of establishing causality because the cause must come before the outcome for the relationship to be considered causal. Here’s why the other options are less appropriate: A. Coherence: Coherence refers to the idea that the observed association should align with existing knowledge and the overall body of evidence. The cause and effect should make sense in the context of what is already known, but it is not specifically about the sequence of events (cause preceding effect). C. Biological plausibility: This criterion suggests that the causal relationship should make sense biologically, based on what is known about biology and the mechanisms at play. While important, it doesn't specifically focus on the order of cause and effect. D. Specificity: Specificity refers to the idea that a single cause leads to a specific effect, and the effect should not have multiple causes. While useful, this is not directly related to the temporal relationship between cause and effect.

questions.text: Association of high altitude areas with goitre is example of :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Indirect association. Explanation: The association between high altitude areas and goitre is an indirect association because it is not the altitude itself that causes goitre, but rather the factors associated with high altitudes, such as iodine deficiency in the environment. In many high-altitude regions, the soil and water are poor in iodine, leading to insufficient iodine intake in the population, which in turn increases the risk of goitre. The high altitude is linked to the presence of iodine deficiency, not the disease directly. Incorrect Options: A. Causal association: A causal association implies that one factor directly causes the outcome, which is not the case here. The high altitude does not directly cause goitre; it's the related environmental factor (iodine deficiency) that plays the direct role. B. Direct association: A direct association would imply that high altitude itself is directly causing goitre, which, as explained, is not accurate. C. Temporal association: Temporal association refers to the timing of exposure and outcome. This isn't the main issue here, as the association is more about environmental factors than about timing.

questions.text: Association can be measured by all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cronbach’s alpha. Explanation: Cronbach’s alpha is a measure of internal consistency or reliability, not an association. It is used to assess the reliability of a scale or a test, indicating how closely related a set of items are in measuring a single construct. It does not measure the association between variables, so it is not relevant to assessing associations in epidemiological studies. Here’s why the other options are correct for measuring associations: A. Relative risk: This is a measure of association often used in cohort studies. It compares the risk of an outcome in an exposed group to the risk in an unexposed group. C. P value: While the p value itself doesn't measure association, it helps to test the statistical significance of an association. A small p-value suggests that the observed association is unlikely to be due to chance. D. Odds ratio: This is a measure of association commonly used in case-control studies. It compares the odds of an exposure in people with the disease to the odds of exposure in people without the disease.

questions.text: A new antibody based rapid kit is invented by ICMR to detect COVID-19. out of 1000 PCR positive patient, 100 are negative on this rapid kit and out of 1000 PCR negative patient 200 are positive. Which of the following is not true?
questions.solution: Answer D. • SENSITIVITY = 900/900+100 = 0.9 OR 90% • SPECIFICITY= 800/800+200= 0.8 OR 80% • PPV= 900/900+200= 81% • NPV = 800/800+100= 88.9%

questions.text: A new screening test is developed for early detection of prostrate cancer. This screening test is on the basis of some genetic markers. The test is positive in 25% affected patients and 10% healthy individuals. If this test is applied to a population where disease prevalence is 10% then how many false positives would you expect per 1000 individuals in this given population?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • 25% affected are positive and 10% not affected are positive • Suppose total population is 1000 • Prev is 10% i.e 100 people affected and 900 not affected. • 10% of health are positive So 10% of 900 are positive. Answer is 90 Incorrect Options: Option B (900 False Positives) This would mean that all 900 healthy individuals test positive, which is incorrect. The false positive rate is 10%, not 100%. Option C (810 False Positives) 810 false positives would mean that 90% of healthy individuals tested positive, which is incorrect because the given false positive rate is only 10%. Option D (990 False Positives) This number is greater than the total number of healthy individuals (900), which is impossible.

Decreased prevalence of HIV in the tested population

questions.text: You are assessing the efficacy of a new screening test for HIV by comparing it with an existing gold standard PCR. Which of the following is most likely to increase the negative predictive value for this test?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • PPV is directly proportional to prevalence • NPV is inversely proportional to prevalence • So, decreased prevalence will increase NPV Incorrect Options: Option A (Increased prevalence of HIV in the tested population) Higher disease prevalence means more infected individuals in the population. This leads to an increase in false negatives (FN), reducing NPV because the denominator (TN+FN) increases while TN remains relatively unchanged. Option C (Increased number of false positive test results) False positives (FP) affect Positive Predictive Value (PPV), not NPV.Since NPV is based on true negatives and false negatives, an increase in FP does not directly impact it. Option D (Increased number of false negative test results) False negatives (FN) reduce NPV because more people with the disease are incorrectly classified as negative. This makes it harder to trust a negative test result, decreasing NPV rather than increasing it.

questions.text: The association between low birth weight and maternal smoking during pregnancy can be studied by obtaining smoking histories from women at the time of the first prenatal visit and then subsequently assessing and assigning birth weight at delivery according to smoking histories. What type of study is this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Prospective Cohort Study) A prospective cohort study follows a group of individuals forward in time to examine the relationship between an exposure (maternal smoking) and an outcome (low birth weight). In this study, pregnant women are assessed at their first prenatal visit (before birth), meaning smoking history is collected before the outcome (birth weight) occurs. The study tracks birth outcomes (low birth weight) as they occur in the future, making it a prospective cohort study. Incorrect Options: Option A (Retrospective Cohort) – Incorrect A retrospective cohort study collects both exposure and outcome data from past records. In this case, researchers are not using past records but are following pregnancies as they progress, making it a prospective study rather than retrospective. Option B (Cross-Sectional) – Incorrect A cross-sectional study measures both exposure and outcome at a single point in time. This study follows participants over time, so it is not cross-sectional. Option D (Case-Control) – Incorrect A case-control study starts with individuals who already have the outcome (low birth weight) and then looks back to determine exposure (smoking). Here, we are starting with pregnant women (before birth) and tracking them forward, making it not a case-control study.

questions.text: Which of the following measures is used frequently as a denominator to calculate the incidence rate of a disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The incidence rate is a measure of the frequency with which a disease or other incident occurs over a specified time period. It is also known as the incidence density rate or person-time incidence rate, when the denominator is the combined person-time of the population at risk (the sum of the time duration of exposure across all persons exposed). For example, if a population initially contains 1,000 persons and 28 develop a condition. In this example, the incidence rate is 14 cases per 1000 person-years, because the incidence proportion (28 per 1,000) is divided by the number of years (two). Using person-time rather than just time handles situations where the amount of observation time differs between people, or when the population at risk varies with time. Use of this measure implies the assumption that the incidence rate is constant over different periods of time, such that for an incidence rate of 14 per 1000 persons-years, 14 cases would be expected for 1000 persons observed for 1 year or 50 persons observed for 20 years.

questions.text: The health ministry of govt. of India conduced a survey in a village, the results of a study of the incidence of pulmonary tuberculosis in the village are given in the following table. All persons in the village are examined during two surveys made two years apart, and the number of new cases was used to determine the incidence rate. What is the incidence of new cases per 1000 person-years in households that had a culture-positive case during the first survey?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) (10 per 1000 person-years) The incidence rate measures the occurrence of new cases of a disease in a specific population over a set period of time. It is calculated as: Incidence Rate=(New Cases/Total Person-years) x 1000 Incorrect Options: Option A (0.02) • 0.02 per 1000 person-years is an extremely low incidence rate, which is unlikely for tuberculosis, especially in high-risk households. Option B (0.01) • Similar to option A, this rate is too low and does not match the calculated incidence from the given data. Option C (1.0) • 1.0 per 1000 person-years is a lower incidence rate than what is found in high-risk settings, such as households with culture-positive cases of TB.

choices.text: In experimental study the investigators determine who is and who is not exposed to the suspected causal factor
In experimental study case and control groups are selected on the basis of history of exposure to the suspected causal factor.

questions.text: During a community medicine lecture your professor asks you to tell a difference between between an experimental study and an observational study. Which of the following would be a correct answer by you ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In an experimental study, the investigators determine who is and who is not exposed to the suspected causal factor. Experimental studies involve direct intervention by researchers. They assign participants to different groups (exposed vs. non-exposed) and then observe the outcomes. These studies include randomized controlled trials (RCTs), where the investigator actively controls the exposure to the suspected causal factor. For example, in a clinical trial for a new drug, researchers decide who will receive the drug (exposed group) and who will receive a placebo (non-exposed group). Incorrect Options: Option A: "The experimental study is prospective" While most experimental studies are prospective, not all are. Some experimental studies, like non-randomized interventions, can analyze past data. Observational studies, on the other hand, can be prospective or retrospective. Option B: "The experimental study is retrospective" Retrospective studies analyze past exposure and outcomes, which is typical for case-control studies. However, experimental studies usually start in the present and follow participants into the future (prospective). Option D: "In experimental study, case and control groups are selected based on history of exposure to the suspected causal factor" This describes an observational case-control study, where participants are selected based on past exposure and then assessed for outcomes. In experimental studies, researchers actively assign exposure rather than selecting based on past exposure.

questions.text: You are newly appointed as an epidemiologist at a “National cancer institute”, you are asked to recommend the type of study appropriate to the needs of researchers who would like to study the causes of a rare form of sarcoma. They have discovered a registry of this form of cancer and have access to the largest database of patients with this form of cancer, which, unfortunately, is only a few years old. They have funding for only one year from the Health Ministry of Govt. Of India and note the budget will be tight. What type of study design do you recommend?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) (Case-Control Study) A case-control study is the most suitable study design for this scenario because: Rare Disease: Since sarcoma is a rare cancer, a case-control study is ideal as it starts with individuals who already have the disease (cases) and compares them to those who do not (controls). This helps identify potential risk factors efficiently. Existing Registry: The researchers have access to a cancer registry, meaning they already have a database of affected patients. This makes it easier to select cases and find suitable controls for comparison. Short Timeframe: A case-control study is retrospective, meaning it analyzes past exposures rather than waiting for disease development. Since funding is limited to one year, a prospective study would take too long. Budget Constraints: Case-control studies are cost-effective compared to cohort or experimental studies, making them feasible within a tight budget. Incorrect Options: A. Prospective Cohort Prospective cohort studies follow a group of people over time to see who develops the disease. This would require several years, making it impractical given the one-year funding limit. Additionally, since the disease is rare, a large sample size would be needed, increasing costs. B. Retrospective Cohort Retrospective cohort studies use past data to compare exposed vs. non-exposed groups and see who developed the disease. However, the cancer registry is only a few years old, meaning it may not have long-term exposure data, making this design less suitable. D. Experimental Experimental studies (like RCTs) involve actively assigning exposure (e.g., testing a new treatment), which is not feasible for studying disease causes. They are also expensive and time-consuming, making them impractical given the budget and time constraints.
