questions.text: A study is being conducted to compare the RAC test (“Ring Around-the-Cholera” test ) for cholera vs the gold standard test for cholera, the researcher performs the test on 100 patients known to have cholera and 100 patients known not to have cholera with the following results: Which of the following statements is incorrect about the RAC test?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sensitivity and specificity mathematically describe the accuracy of a test which reports the presence or absence of a condition, in comparison to a ‘Gold Standard’ or definition. Sensitivity refers to the proportion of those who have the condition (when judged by the ‘Gold Standard’) that received a positive result on this test. Specificity refers to the proportion of those who do not have the condition (when judged by the ‘Gold Standard’) that received a negative result on this test. In a diagnostic test, sensitivity is a measure of how well a test can identify true positives and specificity is a measure of how well a test can identify true negatives. For all testing, both diagnostic and screening, there is usually a trade-off between sensitivity and specificity, such that higher sensitivities will mean lower specificities and vice versa.

choices.text: Treatment and control groups are alike in all respects except treatment

questions.text: The NACO is conducting a randomized clinical trial to examine the effect of a new combination of antiretroviral drugs on HIV viral load compared to usual therapy. Randomization is used for allocation of subjects to either treatment or control groups in experimental studies. Randomization ensures that
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Randomization is the use of a predetermined plan of allocation or assignment of subjects to treatment groups such that assignment occurs solely by chance. It is used to eliminate bias on the part of the investigator and the subject in the choice of treatment group. The goal of randomization is to allow chance to distribute unknown sources of biologic variability equally to the treatment and control groups. In the simplest trial design, the investigational group receives the new treatment and the control group receives standard therapy. At several points during and at the end of the clinical trial, researchers compare the groups to see which treatment is more effective or has fewer side effects. Randomization helps prevent bias. Bias occurs when a trial's results are affected by human choices or other factors not related to the treatment being tested.

questions.text: A community medicine scholar has collected the following data regarding lung cancer and smoking: • Incidence rate of lung cancer in smokers - 120/100,000 person years • Incidence rate of lung cancer in non smokers - 10/100,000 person years • Prevalence of smoking in the community - 20% What percentage of lung cancer can be attributed to smoking?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Attributable risk (AR) or risk difference is the difference between the incidence rates in exposed and non-exposed groups. In a cohort study, AR is calculated as the difference in cumulative incidences (risk difference) or incidence densities (rate difference). This reflects the absolute risk of the exposure or the excess risk of the outcome (e.g. disease) in the exposed group compared with the non-exposed group. AR is sometimes referred to as attributable risk in the exposed because it is used to quantify risk in the exposed group that is attributable to the exposure.

questions.text: A clinical researcher has completed the data collection for a case-control study to measure the association between alcohol use and lower respiratory tract infections. The most appropriate method to control for smoking as a confounder is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) (Stratification) In a case-control study, confounders like smoking can distort the association between alcohol use and lower respiratory tract infections. Stratification is one of the best ways to control for confounders in analysis by dividing the data into subgroups (or strata) based on the confounding variable (in this case, smoking status). For example, the researcher could analyze the relationship between alcohol use and lower respiratory tract infections separately for smokers and non-smokers, helping to isolate the true effect of alcohol use. This ensures that smoking does not skew the results. Incorrect Options: B. Restriction Restriction involves excluding individuals with the confounding factor (e.g., only including non-smokers in the study). While it effectively eliminates confounding, it limits generalizability and reduces the sample size. Since the study has already collected data, restriction cannot be applied retrospectively. C. Randomization Randomization is the best method to control for confounders in randomized controlled trials (RCTs), but not in case-control studies. Since case-control studies select cases and controls based on disease status (not randomly assigned exposure status), randomization cannot be used here. D. Matching Matching involves selecting controls that have similar characteristics (e.g., same smoking status) as the cases to balance confounders. While matching is a good method for controlling confounding in the design phase of a case-control study, it is not useful after data collection has already been completed. Also, overmatching can lead to reduced statistical power.

questions.text: Point prevalence studies tend to overestimate the occurrence of which of the following diseases?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Prevalence is equal to incidence times the duration of disease, or P = I × D. The longer the duration of the disease, the more likely it is to be present at any given time. If a disease has a high mortality rate (short duration), it is unlikely to be counted at any time. Prevalence of disease will increase when a new treatment decreases mortality. A high incidence of disease may or may not have an impact on prevalence: it will depend on its duration and mortality rate Incorrect Options: A. Diseases with a high incidence Incidence refers to the number of new cases over a period of time, whereas prevalence includes both new and existing cases. Diseases with high incidence but short duration (like the flu or acute gastroenteritis) will not necessarily be overestimated because many cases resolve quickly and may not be present at the time of measurement. C. Diseases with a high mortality Diseases with high mortality (such as Ebola or aggressive cancers) tend to reduce prevalence because patients die quickly, leading to underestimation rather than overestimation in point prevalence studies. If a disease has a high mortality rate, there will be fewer existing cases at any given point in time. D. Diseases with a short duration Short-duration diseases (e.g., common cold, influenza, gastroenteritis) are less likely to be captured in a point prevalence study because they resolve quickly. Since point prevalence only captures cases present at a specific moment, many short-duration cases may be missed, leading to underestimation rather than overestimation.

questions.text: Higher lead levels in hyperactive children may be due to increased consumption of paint in children who were already hyperactive. Consider the following study and pick the appropriate epidemiologic term.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) (Selection Bias) Selection bias occurs when the method used to select study participants results in a sample that is not representative of the population being studied. In this case, hyperactive children may be more likely to consume lead-containing paint, leading to higher lead levels. If these children were selected into the study based on their high lead levels without considering the underlying reason (hyperactivity itself leading to more paint consumption), this introduces selection bias—specifically, a type of bias where the exposure (lead) and outcome (hyperactivity) are not independent of selection into the study. Thus, selection bias is the most appropriate epidemiologic term for this scenario. Incorrect Options: A. Confounding Confounding occurs when a third variable is associated with both the exposure and the outcome but is not on the causal pathway. Here, hyperactivity leads to increased paint consumption (lead exposure), which in turn increases blood lead levels. Since hyperactivity itself is the reason for exposure, this is not an example of confounding. C. Differential Misclassification Differential misclassification happens when measurement errors systematically differ between groups (e.g., if lead exposure was measured more accurately in hyperactive children than in non-hyperactive children). However, this scenario is not about measurement errors but rather about how the study selects participants based on their lead levels, making it selection bias, not misclassification bias. D. Lead-time Bias Lead-time bias occurs when early detection of a disease falsely appears to improve survival time, simply because the disease was detected earlier rather than actually prolonging life. This concept is irrelevant to the given scenario, as it deals with exposure (lead) and behavior (hyperactivity), not early detection of disease.

questions.text: Survey conducted in a rural area shows that children between the ages of 1 and 5 years have an average of eight colds per year. Choose the rate that best describes the statement.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) (Morbidity Rate) The morbidity rate refers to the frequency or occurrence of a disease within a specified population during a given time period. In this case, the survey measures how often children (ages 1-5) experience colds per year. Since colds are a form of illness but not fatal, the most appropriate epidemiological measure is morbidity rate, which captures the burden of disease within a population. Incorrect Options: A. Secondary Attack Rate – Incorrect Secondary attack rate measures the spread of an infectious disease within a specific group, such as within households or close contacts after exposure to an infected person. Since the data provided here does not distinguish between primary and secondary cases, this is not a secondary attack rate scenario. B. Case Fatality Rate – Incorrect Case fatality rate (CFR) is the proportion of people who die from a disease among those who have it. Since colds are not fatal illnesses, CFR does not apply here. D. Age-Adjusted Mortality – Incorrect Age-adjusted mortality rate is a statistical measure used to compare death rates across populations while controlling for age differences. The data provided concerns illness frequency, not mortality, making this option irrelevant.

questions.text: In a cohort study conducted to study the relation of hypertension related factors with age of the patient. The proportions of subjects with high and low renin levels who survived for five years are compared separately among those aged 40 to 49, those aged 50 to 59, and those aged 60 to 69 at entry. Choose the term that best fits the description of study.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) (Stratification) Explanation: Stratification is the process of dividing study participants into subgroups (strata) based on specific characteristics, such as age groups, gender, or disease severity. In this cohort study, age groups (40–49, 50–59, and 60–69 years) are used to separately compare survival rates among subjects with high and low renin levels. This method helps control for confounding by ensuring comparisons are made within homogeneous subgroups, leading to a more accurate assessment of the relationship between renin levels and survival. Incorrect Options: A. Matching Matching is a technique used in case-control studies where participants are paired based on similar characteristics (e.g., age, gender) to control for confounding. This study is a cohort study, and instead of matching, it divides participants into strata based on age, making stratification the correct approach. C. Survival Analysis Survival analysis is a statistical method used to examine the time until an event occurs (e.g., death, disease progression). While the study does examine 5-year survival rates, it does not focus on modeling survival probabilities over time using techniques like Kaplan-Meier curves or Cox proportional hazards models, which are typical of survival analysis. D. Multivariate Statistical Analysis Multivariate analysis is used to examine the effect of multiple variables simultaneously using regression models (e.g., logistic regression, multiple linear regression). This study compares survival within age-defined subgroups rather than analyzing multiple variables simultaneously, making stratification the more appropriate term.

questions.text: A randomized blinded trial of aspirin to prevent myocardial infarction fails to find a difference between aspirin and placebo groups after five years (N = 500 per group; p = 0.11). This study demonstrates
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) (Type 2 Error) A Type 2 error (? error) occurs when a study fails to detect a real effect when one actually exists. In this randomized blinded trial, aspirin might truly prevent myocardial infarction (MI), but the study did not find a statistically significant difference (p = 0.11). The p-value (0.11) means the study failed to reject the null hypothesis (no difference between aspirin and placebo). However, since the sample size is moderate (500 per group), there may have been insufficient statistical power to detect a true effect. A Type 2 error happens when the study lacks power, meaning there may have been a real effect, but the study could not detect it due to sample size, variability, or effect size being too small. Thus, the study failed to detect an actual effect of aspirin, leading to a Type 2 error. Incorrect Options: A. Ecologic Fallacy An ecologic fallacy occurs when conclusions about individuals are drawn from group-level data. This study is a randomized controlled trial (RCT), not an ecological study, so this is not applicable. B. Type 1 Error A Type 1 error (? error) occurs when a study incorrectly rejects the null hypothesis, meaning it finds a significant effect when there is none. Here, the study did not find a significant result (p = 0.11), meaning it failed to reject the null hypothesis, which is characteristic of a Type 2 error, not Type 1. D. Selection Bias Selection bias occurs when the way participants are chosen systematically influences the results. This is a randomized trial, where participants were assigned to aspirin or placebo randomly, minimizing selection bias. Since the issue here is failing to detect a true difference, not biased selection, selection bias is not the correct answer.

choices.text: The health care system of the developing country is far better than that in the developed country.
More people die in the developed country because it has a larger population.
Crude death rates are usually higher in developed countries because of a higher proportion of older persons in the population
Death rates in the developing country are lower due to the emigration effect.

questions.text: The crude death rate in a developed european country is 150/100,000. The crude death rate in a smaller developing african country is 75/100,000. Based on these data, which one of the following statements best explains the data?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) (Crude death rates are usually higher in developed countries because of a higher proportion of older persons in the population) The crude death rate (CDR) is the number of deaths per 100,000 population per year. While it may seem surprising that a developed European country has a higher CDR (150/100,000) than a developing African country (75/100,000), this can be explained by differences in population age distribution. Developed countries have an aging population due to lower birth rates, better healthcare, and longer life expectancy. Since older people naturally have a higher mortality rate, the overall crude death rate appears higher. Developing countries have younger populations due to higher birth rates and lower life expectancy. Since younger populations have lower mortality rates, the crude death rate appears lower even if healthcare and living conditions are worse. Crude death rates do not account for age distribution, which is why age-adjusted mortality rates are more useful when comparing different countries. Thus, Option C is correct: Developed countries tend to have higher crude death rates due to a larger proportion of elderly individuals. Incorrect Options: A. "The healthcare system of the developing country is far better than that in the developed country." If the developing country had a better healthcare system, we would expect lower infant mortality, fewer deaths from infectious diseases, and longer life expectancy, which is unlikely given economic and healthcare disparities. The lower crude death rate is not due to better healthcare but rather a younger population. B. "More people die in the developed country because it has a larger population." The crude death rate is expressed per 100,000 people, so population size does not influence the rate. Even if the developed country has a larger population, the rate itself is standardized, meaning this statement is misleading. D. "Death rates in the developing country are lower due to the emigration effect." While some emigration of young and healthy individuals may occur, it is not a major factor influencing the crude death rate. The primary reason for a lower crude death rate in the developing country is its younger population, not emigration.
